Resubmitted this patch without calling notifications on endpoints and services since there needs to be some additional discussion as to where to put it. The previous implementation for notifications in endpoints and services gave this: 

http://paste.openstack.org/show/45035/

Which sends three notifications with the wrong IDs.. Moving to  keystone/catalog/controllers.py fixes the problem but then we have an inconsistency with whether the notifications should be called within the Managers (users/projects) or the controllers... Sending notifications in the Managers for users and projects works fine, so that is what the patch now targets.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-23 17:35:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Implement decorator-based notifications for users

Refactors the keystone.notifications module to use decorators, and
applies those new decorators to user CRUD operations at the manager
layer.

blueprint notifications

Change-Id: Ic7937657196a0ad19923153a5135b1451a533e81

'}, {'created': '2013-08-09 08:54:23.000000000', 'message': "Add PCI device tracker to compute resource tracker

PCI device tracker manage all the PCI devices life cycle.

Resouce tracker of compute node use PCI tracker's interface
to test resouce, claim the PCI devices, alloc and free the
instance's PCI devices.

bp:pci-passthrough-base

Change-Id: I766d7f92e26fb75c1d6095dc0237c44f938d4170

commit_message:
Add PCI device tracker to compute resource tracker

PCI device tracker manages all the PCI devices life cycle.

The resource tracker on a compute node uses the PCI device tracker's
interface to query for resources, claim PCI devices, and alloc and
free PCI devices for instances.

bp:pci-passthrough-base

Change-Id: I766d7f92e26fb75c1d6095dc0237c44f938d4170
Signed-off-by: Yongli He <yongli.he@intel.com>
Signed-off-by: Yunhong Jiang <yunhong.jiang@intel.com>

commit_message:
Adds Instance UUID to rsync debug logging

This commit adds the instance uuid to the rsync debug output in
the debug logs. The issue we were seeing is that when multiple
migrations are ongoing at the same time, it's not easy to
track the rsync progress of each migration.
Fixes: bug #1215629

Change-Id: Iec662bdc0aed1c6f54ecaa062335dc5504ac030f

Might it be more efficient to try an object PUT, and then on 404, try container PUT? Right now you wind up with at least 1 request per container, plus one request per object. If you only PUT the container on failure, you'd eliminate a bunch of requests when the containers already existed."}, {'account_id': 995, 'date': '2013-07-25 19:36:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I thought about that and would be kinda cool but the problem is that i'm dealing with an input stream so after I'd have to use the 100 continue thing and it would be pretty complicated. I don't think the extra head for each container is that big of a deal especially because the object put does a container HEAD anyway that will now be cached."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-07-25 19:38:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Oh yeah, I forgot about all that caching stuff.

commit_message:
Allow users to extract tars to containers with ACLs set

This fixes bug: https://bugs.launchpad.net/swift/+bug/1203182 (well
it should :) I don't have keystone installed but the same issue
existed with tempauth).

Change-Id: I6f4045f484b27c0153a9244e0dbf2641cbc9e84e

[{'created': '2013-08-25 10:19:01.000000000', 'message': "Avoid swallowing exceptions in _allocate_fixed_ips()

In _allocate_fixed_ips(), we spawn off green threads to call
_rpc_allocate_fixed_ip() on remote network managers, but if there is an
exception in the thread it just gets swallowed.

We don't really need a GreenPool here. It's not like its limit of 1000
threads is relevant here. Just use eventlet.spawn(), collect the list of
threads spawned and call wait() on each of them. This will ensure the
exception gets raised by wait().

Also, fix a case in the v3 integrated servers test where we are setting
up fake networks which are associated with a non-existent 'fake-mini'
host. See also I9854863bbec8834c638c55832411f63da570f82d.

commit_message:
Avoid swallowing exceptions in network manager

In _allocate_fixed_ips() and setup_networks_on_host(), we spawn off
green threads to call _rpc_allocate_fixed_ip() and
rpc_setup_network_on_host() on remote network managers, but if there is
an exception in the thread it just gets swallowed.

We don't really need a GreenPool here. It's not like its limit of 1000
threads is relevant here. Just use eventlet.spawn(), collect the list of
threads spawned and call wait() on each of them. This will ensure the
exception gets raised by wait().

Also, fix a case in the v3 integrated servers test where we are setting
up fake networks which are associated with a non-existent 'fake-mini'
host. See also I9854863bbec8834c638c55832411f63da570f82d.

blueprint: oslo-messaging
Change-Id: I7af1c4c1869edf3601809fe02fb82b12c8b70811

[{'created': '2013-08-30 20:25:13.000000000', 'message': 'Two small performance improvements to header generation

These both apply to the proxy servers:

First, instead of consturction a dict just to use with `.update()` simply set a
set of keys in the headers dict.

Second, generating the headers for proxy requests once, no matter how many
backend servers are accessed (instead of once per backend server), they all get
the same headers.

Change-Id: Ib42bf7750e175a6ad9b777fa35655380feeafb93
'}]
commit_message:
Two small performance improvements to header generation

These both apply to the proxy servers:

First, instead of consturction a dict just to use with `.update()` simply set a
set of keys in the headers dict.

Second, generating the headers for proxy requests once, no matter how many
backend servers are accessed (instead of once per backend server), they all get
the same headers.

Change-Id: Ib42bf7750e175a6ad9b777fa35655380feeafb93

it's definitely weird to me to land something in devstack that's not at minimum in stackforge. Having this dependent on an fully external git tree which we can't gate on is really odd.

I read the nova reviews for this though that wanted to wait on devstack... so I'm a bit torn."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-08-10 10:48:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(5 inline comments)

some additional questions / inline comments."}, {'account_id': 7838, 'date': '2013-08-12 16:52:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: (4 inline comments)

I started to answer the stackforge question inline. Basically I wanted to be on Stackforge first. Being new to OpenStack in general, I asked one guy on IRC who told me that the project was not big enough to justify a Stackforge project. It makes sense regarding the existing ones. In anyway, I am open to this and I guess Monty is the maintainer of it, so I'll ask him.

Thanks for the feedback."}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2013-08-12 19:18:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

This is the first time we've landed a new hypervisor in this order (DevStack-first rather than Nova-first).  Maybe we need some way to indicate not-ready-for-prime-time bits?"}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-08-12 19:24:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: No score

Ok, due to timing, and the desire from the nova side to get something into devstack, I'm back to 0 (though please fix the hard tab before landing).

I think like Dean says, we probably need to sort out the policy for landing in new hypervisors that everyone agrees to. (Like when do things go to stackforge, which pieces need to be in devstack before the nova patch gets looked at, what tests need to land before the nova patch is approved, etc.) Which I think is probably a Nova session that at least includes me, Monty, and Dean in the mix to get the outside of nova parts sorted."}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2013-08-16 20:56:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-16 21:47:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

commit_message:
Add support for Docker as Nova hypervisor

* Add basic support for hypervisor plugins in lib/nova_plugins
* Add lib/nova_plugins/hypervisor-docker to use Docker as a Nova
  hypervisor.
* Add tools/install_docker.sh to install the Docker daemon and
  registry container, download base image and import
* Configure Nova to use docker plugin
* Add docker exercise and skip unsupported ones

Nova blueprint: new-hypervisor-docker

Change-Id: I9e7065b562dce2ce853def583ab1165886612227

commit_message:
Standardize base.py with novaclient

Main changes:
* deprecate api variable in favour of client
* add documentation
* use to_slug from oslo strutils
* remove Python 2.4 support
* other small fixes from novaclient

Change-Id: Ife54fd3207798ee03101a48bc1cda3b3f62cc5e4

commit_message:
Fixing potential NameErrors

Fixing a couple locations that could potentially raise NameErrors
instead of intended exceptions.  These were found by looking at
flake8 F821 (undefined name) errors.

Added in unit tests to verify NameErrors would not be raised.

Change-Id: I8619cb0be495b814335a5aea23daca025484d3c6

I am concerned that this change, by using the quotas API may be in conflict with that change.  My concern is that Horizon is moving in a unified direction."}, {'account_id': 5623, 'date': '2013-05-28 16:37:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

This looks good to me otherwise, thank you for the patch!

Thank you for the update, and the info on fixed_ips quotas.

A couple more questions... I notice snapshots is being specifically excluded now (it wasn't in patch set 2). Why is that?

This made me curious so I looked at the other quotas and I notice there are a couple more missing (e.g. key pairs, injected file path bytes). Any reason?

The CINDER_QUOTA updates don't currently work, probably because https://review.openstack.org/#/c/30226/ isn't merged yet? I think we should wait for 30226 to be merged and a new release of cinderclient to be made first, so we can update the requirements file. It's a bit misleading otherwise."}, {'account_id': 4428, 'date': '2013-06-07 02:38:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 4428, 'date': '2013-06-07 02:43:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

'}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2013-06-17 20:50:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

The code generally looks good, but I have a more esoteric question... the 'System Info' panel was originally created to be a home for "read-only" data about the system. It was, in fact, meant to eliminate the confusion around why we were displaying the default quotas when they weren't editable. So now we're reversing that decision and I'm wondering if it makes sense to keep this in "System Info" anymore. Perhaps it would fit better in a new panel called "Defaults" or something. The default security group rules are also editable in Nova now, so that could live there as well.

Thoughts?'}, {'account_id': 4428, 'date': '2013-06-18 00:28:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

+1 @Gabriel'}, {'account_id': 4428, 'date': '2013-06-20 07:41:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-20 08:24:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Works for me

commit_message:
Allow admins to update default quotas

Add update default quotas form to edit the default quotas.

Move the editable default quotas tab to a new panel called
"Defaults".

Implements blueprint edit-default-quota

Change-Id: I6e3806226cd2f699f16b93c25e294bc67883738f

commit_message:
Add apiclient.exceptions hierarchy

The new apiclient.exceptions hierarchy is more comprehensive
and it covers almost all HTTP error status codes. These
exceptions can be used in novaclient, keystoneclient,
glanceclient, and other client projects thus providing a
single inteface.

Users can have benefit from OpenStack clients raising exceptions
of known classes while now every client has its own classes making
difficult to catch, e.g., NotFound for every client.

Change-Id: Ia7b25880e0ffca3526525a0f0e77c7e77c4f0076

commit_message:
Missing space at the end of the conditional expression

Missing space in the expression which enables the exercises on the
stable jobs.

The '==' changed to '=' in order to be more POSIX.

Change-Id: Icd43d15b9d00ed9a8fbc38a8e7217be2bd0de9d1

commit_message:
Replace auth_token middleware tests with httpretty

Httpretty will work in exactly the same way regardless of whether we use
the httplib or requests library. Convert it so we can modify the
middleware and know that our tests are still correct.

In this process we also split the tests from having V3 tests override
V2 tests, to having a base test class and V2 and V3 seperate overrides.

Change-Id: I1bfcecc6ae47a6dd5e76d4ceb8b3941e6ad1089f

commit_message:
Object API commands using our REST API layer

* Add object-store API to ClientManager
* Add object-store client
* Add Object API library in openstackclient.object.v1.lib
* Add Object API {container,object} list commands
* Add library tests
* Add command tests

This should complete the Object v1 container and object list commands

Change-Id: Ib1770d45efa8871959826b85faafa1e0bcef0a03

commit_message:
Delete and launch devices on the topology view

This feature enables to delete and launch a instance or router on the network
topology view. So you can do basic actions on this view.
Also it enables to change view small or normal. You can see more networks and
devices in the small view.

implements bp editable-network-topology-view

fixes bug #1215683

Change-Id: Ie65d50d2a99f72696c8f10223f8430ad5f90b144

(1 inline comment)

Good start. Perhaps we can add the following if they don't already exist in other docs?

1. How to configure the notification drivers in keystone.conf? i.e. user can configure one or more notification drivers in keystone.conf. All drivers are notified.

2. How to develop your own custom notification driver. i.e. by implementing the notify() method.

3. An example, like what the create_user event payload looks like."}, {'account_id': 7179, 'date': '2013-08-29 19:17:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 7179, 'date': '2013-08-29 19:23:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (1 inline comment)

Is this intended to be a general document for all Keystone resource notifications or just users?'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-08-29 22:59:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

@Brad: my goal for havana is users and projects at a minimum. it *should* just a matter of plastering these new decorators on other manager methods, but the mess created by assignment_api has complicated that work significantly (see what it takes to add support for projects in... https://review.openstack.org/#/c/43340/ ). I don't *think* any other resources should be affected, but I don't want to commit to any others at this point, either."}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-08-30 01:55:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2013-08-30 02:27:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I am OK with it reflecting what we have currently in master. But this document is incomplete I think. When I look at it, I don't know what to make of it. Yes, it certainly contains some useful information. But what is the goal? Who are the target audience?

Is it for developers who develop against notification framework? In case, would it be more appropriate to update developing.rst? i.e. how to write your own notification driver.

Is it for for architects who want to make use of notification data. It appears what this document is about. In that case, would it make more sense to have it in architecture.rst?

It is for somebody who deploys Keystone? In that case, should we update configuration.rst on how to setup the notification drivers?

Anyway, I am all for more documentations. Just that I think this one may need some more work in the future."}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-08-30 12:28:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

gyee: I think it's fair to say it's pretty much exclusively intended for those looking to consume notifications from keystone, but I'm not sure it belongs in architecture.rst? I like that it's in it's own doc, personally."}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-08-30 12:30:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-08-30 12:31:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Document usage notifications

Adding documentation for the usage notifications being
added to Keystone for bp notifications.

Change-Id: Ibf87d52bc6df68553f346eeba326e9159303313d

commit_message:
Make resource_tracker record host_ip

Now that the host_ip, for affinity_filters, is coming from the DB and
the host_ip is virt driver independent so make the resource_tracker add
it.

part of bp no-compute-fanout-to-scheduler

Change-Id: I498578191b0af97cb91ca0d81b7ad1eeaf8fd995

[{'created': '2013-08-21 18:14:17.000000000', 'message': 'Add "Action in progress" error for multi-engine.

Raises an "Action in progress" error if an action is in progress when
another action is issued.  The engine confirms the "in progress" status
by sending an RPC to the engine doing the work.  If the stack's status
is "in progress", but no response is received, the other engine is
assumed to have died and the action will proceed as usual.

Blueprint multi-engine
Fixes bug #1211276

Change-Id: I9f03a2281e5dea04e45fec61fbdb1120f0a32ef0

commit_message:
Add "Action in progress" error for multi-engine

Raises an "Action in progress" error if an action is in progress when
another action is issued.  The engine confirms the "in progress" status
by sending an RPC to the engine doing the work.  If the stack's status
is "in progress", but no response is received, the other engine is
assumed to have died and the action will proceed as usual.

Blueprint multiple-engines

Change-Id: I9f03a2281e5dea04e45fec61fbdb1120f0a32ef0

commit_message:
Cleanup sections about Multiple Compute Nodes

common/section_multiple-compute-nodes.xml was not used everywhere.
It was introduced with change I0a7fb144241be7acf7c9063e5290220b5d7b7192
that moved content to the Config Guide, thus include it from there.

openstack-install/configuring-multiple-compute-nodes.xml is a duplicate
of common/section_multiple-compute-nodes.xml which was unused as well
and thus removed.

Change-Id: I4d4158ad033d5dd97d17f4f7f3efd0be0ca6801d

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-21 22:10:58.000000000', 'message': 'Implement caching for Tokens

Based upon the keystone caching (using dogpile.cache) implementation
token caching is implemented in this patchset.

This patchset inclues basic Token caching as the first implemntation
of this caching layer.  The following methods are cached:
    * token_api.get_token,
    * token_api.list_revoked_tokens
    * token_provider_api.validate_v3_token
    * token_provider_api.check_v3_token

Calls to token_api.delete_token and token_api.delete_tokens will
properly invalidate the cache for the tokens being acted upon, as
well as invalidating the cache for the revoked_tokens_list.

DocImpact

partial-blueprint: caching-layer-for-driver-calls
Change-Id: Ifada0db0043fede504a091670ccc521196c2f19c

'}, {'created': '2013-08-25 04:26:29.000000000', 'message': 'Implement caching for Tokens and Token Validation

Based upon the keystone caching (using dogpile.cache) implementation
token caching is implemented in this patchset.

This patchset inclues basic Token caching as the first implemntation
of this caching layer.  The following methods are cached:
    * token_api.get_token,
    * token_api.list_revoked_tokens
    * token_provider_api.validate_v3_token
    * token_provider_api.check_v3_token
    * token_provider_api.check_v2_token
    * token_provider_api.validate_v2_token
    * token_provider_api.validate_token

Calls to token_api.delete_token and token_api.delete_tokens will
properly invalidate the cache for the tokens being acted upon, as
well as invalidating the cache for the revoked_tokens_list and the
validate/check token calls.

Token caching is configurable independantly of the revocation_list
caching.

DocImpact

partial-blueprint: caching-layer-for-driver-calls
Change-Id: Ifada0db0043fede504a091670ccc521196c2f19c
'}, {'created': '2013-08-25 07:41:02.000000000', 'message': 'Implement caching for Tokens and Token Validation

'}, {'created': '2013-08-29 09:01:40.000000000', 'message': 'Implement caching for Tokens and Token Validation

Based upon the keystone caching (using dogpile.cache) implementation
token caching is implemented in this patchset.

This patchset inclues basic Token caching as the first implemntation
of this caching layer.  The following methods are cached:
    * token_api.get_token,
    * token_api.list_revoked_tokens
    * token_provider_api.validate_v3_token
    * token_provider_api.check_v3_token
    * token_provider_api.check_v2_token
    * token_provider_api.validate_v2_token
    * token_provider_api.validate_token

Calls to token_api.delete_token and token_api.delete_tokens will
properly invalidate the cache for the tokens being acted upon, as
well as invalidating the cache for the revoked_tokens_list and the
validate/check token calls.

Token caching is configurable independantly of the revocation_list
caching.

Lifted expiration checks from the token drivers to the token manager.
This ensures that cached tokens will still raise TokenNotFound when
expired.

For cache consistency, all token_ids are transformed into the short
token hash at the provider and token_driver level. Some methods would
have access to the full ID (PKI Tokens), and some methods would not.
Cache invalidation is inconsistent without token_id normalization.

DocImpact

commit_message:
Implement caching for Tokens and Token Validation

Based upon the keystone caching (using dogpile.cache) implementation
token caching is implemented in this patchset.

This patchset inclues basic Token caching as the first implementation
of this caching layer.  The following methods are cached:
    * token_api.get_token,
    * token_api.list_revoked_tokens
    * token_provider_api.validate_v3_token
    * token_provider_api.check_v3_token
    * token_provider_api.check_v2_token
    * token_provider_api.validate_v2_token
    * token_provider_api.validate_token

Calls to token_api.delete_token and token_api.delete_tokens will
properly invalidate the cache for the tokens being acted upon, as
well as invalidating the cache for the revoked_tokens_list and the
validate/check token calls.

Token caching is configurable independantly of the revocation_list
caching.

Lifted expiration checks from the token drivers to the token manager.
This ensures that cached tokens will still raise TokenNotFound when
expired.

For cache consistency, all token_ids are transformed into the short
token hash at the provider and token_driver level. Some methods would
have access to the full ID (PKI Tokens), and some methods would not.
Cache invalidation is inconsistent without token_id normalization.

DocImpact

partial-blueprint: caching-layer-for-driver-calls
Change-Id: Ifada0db0043fede504a091670ccc521196c2f19c

commit_message:
Add support for parsing jsonfied heat error

Keep the legacy method for the cases that user may use
an old version of heat.

Fixes bug #1207624
Change-Id: I3346d7a6f8f51746ee5455720f093cd785623634

'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-08-16 22:11:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 16: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

I think the intent of the change is right, but I'd like to see it a little less automatic in terms of what it changes.

Also, this has nothing to do with PowerVM and modifies only core code. I think the commit message needs to be completely rewritten to reflect what the change actually is."}, {'account_id': 7282, 'date': '2013-08-19 02:19:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

For the commit message, there 2 parts, first part describes why the review is submitted, second part describes why no change for PowerVM codes: 
Just change compute manager in this review since review
39107 is doing the other part patch to powervm driver
and powervm test_powervm.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2013-08-19 02:49:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Changing my score since yeah, the commit message should be cleaned up here.  The bug points out that you found this via the powervm driver, but as Dan points out, the change is really not tied to any virt driver but cleans up the flow in the compute manager.

Before change Ieaf256a5c0f54804686318d6cbd5877a5003c9eb, the powervm driver would simply pass on suspend/resume actions which left the instance in SUSPENDED state because the compute manager assumed the virt driver actually suspended it since it didn't error out. Now that the virt driver raises NotImplementedError, the patch here is to change the instance back to it's state before the NotImplementedError was raised, which I think will put it into an ERROR state if we don't have this fix, right?

So maybe the commit message should be something like this:

"Unimplemented suspend/resume should not change vm_state

When the underlying virt driver does not implement the suspend/resume API and raises a NotImplementedError, the compute manager will error out and change the instance's vm_state to ERROR. With this change, the compute manager will handle the NotImplementedError and keep the instance vm_state as it was before the error.

Closes-Bug: #1203986

Change-Id: I8150a898fee91bbe66f1502638baca8050e2dd6d"

I'm starting to have second thoughts about this change now though. Maybe it's better to error out when the user tries to perform an operation that is not supported/implemented by the virt driver as an indication that what they are attempting is wrong. Also, with my change Ieaf256a5c0f54804686318d6cbd5877a5003c9eb, there are other methods besides suspend/resume that are going to raise NotImplementedError but they aren't being covered in this patch (plug_vifs, reboot, host_power_action).  The powervm driver will also raise NotImplementedError on pause/unpause operations but the compute manager is not currently doing anything to handle that case now either.

So this almost seems like it should be a broader change to (1) make sure virt drivers raise NotImplementedError on API methods they don't implement and (2) wrap that error appropriately in the compute manager.'}, {'account_id': 7282, 'date': '2013-08-19 03:19:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

To Matt, Accept your commit message.
For your new idea: error out when the user tries to perform an operation that is not supported/implemented by the virt driver as an indication that what they are attempting is wrong.
This is right, and this should be considered first, but for these suspend, pause.. operations, they are POST requests and the nova client will not receive anything about NotImplemented or others error reported by virt level. So as this change now only write the NotImplenmented indication to compute.log.'}, {'account_id': 7282, 'date': '2013-08-19 05:11:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: (2 inline comments)

commit_message:
Unimplemented suspend/resume should not change vm state

When the underlying virt driver does not implement the suspend/resume API
and raises a NotImplementedError, the compute manager will error out and
change the instance's vm_state to ERROR. With this change, the compute
manager will handle the NotImplementedError and keep the instance
vm_state as it was before the error.

Change-Id: I8150a898fee91bbe66f1502638baca8050e2dd6d
Fixes: bug #1203986

commit_message:
Fix the Domain Context for Users panel

Add display of Domain ID and Domain Name in the Create and Update
Users page to give user a hint where the User will be created.
For Keystone V2, the two fields will be hidden.

When the Domain Context is set, the User will be created in that
Domain Context. Otherwise, the User will be created in the Domain
of the logon user.

On users creation, the listing of available projects will be based
on the Domain where it will be created.

Fixes bug 1215697

Change-Id: I780d11289ab73804d0d26ad71a07ece6b2da74ad

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-30 14:40:09.000000000', 'message': "Defer computation of available methods until needed.

In practice this data is almost only ever needed if we're throwing an
HTTPMethodNotAllowed error, so we can avoid computing on every single
request to the proxy server.

Change-Id: I2abafa3aeb63ca6974dfcf6f31c864c049681f37
"}]
commit_message:
Defer computation of available methods until needed.

In practice this data is almost only ever needed if we're throwing an
HTTPMethodNotAllowed error, so we can avoid computing on every single
request to the proxy server.

Change-Id: I2abafa3aeb63ca6974dfcf6f31c864c049681f37

commit_message:
Added job execution after cluster start and operation for job execution

Implements: blueprint epd-start-job-after-cluster-creation

Change-Id: I37bb3409dd30bd144ca35ac663398726b22b9317

'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-08-30 07:56:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(3 inline comments)

In patch set 4 you said that no code calls these methods, but stated that it will help with upgrades - which is confusing as that means that this code is indeed invoked.
I can understand leaving the method but why do we need to have the current code (which may cause problems). Why not have a log.deprecated method and just return?
Thanks
Gary"}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-08-30 15:44:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Leaving the code around is to support rpcapi backwards compatibility (http://docs.openstack.org/developer/nova/api/nova.openstack.common.rpc.dispatcher.html).

So technically nothing calls this code in trunk, and it will only be called in the case of a live rolling upgrade.  For example nova.scheduler.rpcapi:update_service_capabilities  would only be called when the scheduler is updated to run this code, but the compute nodes have not been upgraded yet.

Sidenote: Currently we don't do any testing of rolling upgrades, but I hope we can gate on a limited case of this, testing grizzly nova-compute with trunk everything else, before Havana is out. 

As far as I know we only use LOG.deprecated for code that someone can potentially use based on how nova is configured, but this isn't one of those cases.

With this in mind, it doesn't seem like useful information to log that this function is being called during a rolling upgrade.  But if I have of respin the patch if you want I can add the deprecated log warning"}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-08-30 16:06:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

agreed that it doesn't make sense to LOG these cases"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-30 16:07:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: No score

commit_message:
Disable compute fanout to scheduler

Now that nothing is using publish_service_capabilities it can be
disabled, but not removed in order to not break compute rpcapi backwards
compatibility.

Part of bp no-compute-fanout-to-scheduler.

Change-Id: I80c49c46138fd6ee89cb08ffbbced72ada4de72e

commit_message:
Make image_props_filter use information from DB not RPC

Make image_props_filter directly use the data from host_state and not
the data from capabilities that is currently broadcast from the
scheduler over RPC, as this will be removed since it doesn't scale.

Once all capabilities usage in scheduler filters is
removed the capabilities RPC broadcast can be removed.

Part of bp no-compute-fanout-to-scheduler.

Change-Id: I5e6bcec517edbf606903c3e98f3c63f7ba370bcf

commit_message:
Make compute_capabilities_filter use information from DB not RPC

Make compute_capabilities_filter directly use the data in host_state and
not the data capabilities data that is currently broadcast from the
schedulers over RPC, as this will be removed since it doesn't scale.

The filter name, compute_capabilities_filter, is kept the same to keep
backwards compatibility.

This is a second attempt at this patch the first one broke the ability
to filter an arbitrary key value pairs, this time that is supported via
host_state.stats, along with tests to confirm

Once all the capabilities usage in scheduler filters is removed, the
capabilities RPC broadcast can be removed.

Part of bp no-compute-fanout-to-scheduler.

Change-Id: I0b9b05a25a8c1841093913c4a2fb19b48aff2ae1

commit_message:
Added Hive configuration, new nodeprocess - hiveserver

* Configuration hive-site.xml for Derby DB
* Added hive-default.xml
* Creating hive warehouse dir in HDFS
* Plugin validation exceptions

Implements blueprint edp-vanilla-plugin-hive-pig

Change-Id: I68b4f1307b8ff565d60d26c415eed1f553b8d5eb

Get rid of pycrypto dep

* ssh keys are generated with ssh-keygen now;
* most of the code is ported from nova.

Change-Id: I9cbf4bbff481c3a414b825abbe030ea27b7a2b63

You have pep8 failures -- see the jenkins pep8 run for details."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-06-07 19:57:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 4912, 'date': '2013-06-10 14:20:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

There are unnecessary and possibly breaking changes in here IMHO. I think all you need to do is change the DirectPublisher to not be durable and that will solve the bug. No need for an extra flag for this, it just doesn't make sense to have them be durable.

I worry about all the other changes, it looks like you are breaking support for qpid versions older than .20. I believe the EPEL/RHEL version is .14 which doesn't have full support for AMPQ 1.0. Can you confirm this doesn't break on at least the RHEL rpms?"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-06-10 15:34:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-06-10 21:15:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

What's the smallest change that can be made here to fix the bug at hand?  There is too much mixed up in this one patch."}, {'account_id': 2349, 'date': '2013-06-11 03:00:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-06-11 03:00:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Can you address all of the questions/concerns raised so far?

Also, what about backwards compatibility with the code before these changes?'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-06-11 15:05:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

To clarify what info I'm looking for:

1) What version of qpidd and/or python-qpidclient are needed to support this.  Is it any different from before this change?

2) What are the backwards compatibility implications of this change with the code as it was before?  It looks like it totally breaks it.

3) Is there any more minimal change to fix the bug?  This seems to mix up some major refactoring with addressing a bug.

4) We can't use a static exchange name.  The code gets shared among multiple projects.  If they're all sharing the same exchange, they will conflict when they use the same topics, right?"}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-06-11 15:17:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-06-11 15:22:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Relevant note I just left on the bug: 

"It appears that this issue is grizzly specific.  It's (accidentally) fixed in havana already.

In havana, we use a single queue for all replies.  We're not creating an exchange/queue for every reply.  This behavior was actually introduced in grizzly, but is off by default.  If you set amqp_rpc_single_reply_queue=True in your config file, you should not be seeing this problem."'}, {'account_id': 2349, 'date': '2013-06-11 18:33:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

1) What version of qpidd and/or python-qpidclient are needed to support this. Is it any different from before this change?

Answer: any modern version , i.e. 0.14 and on  - so no problem there.

2) What are the backwards compatibility implications of this change with the code as it was before? It looks like it totally breaks it.

Answer: I doubt it. The only issue I would see is if there is a instance that is somehow using an older clinet. I would assume that Openstack env. are generally using the same version across the cloud. Could instances be living across an upgrade? The only area would be in a federated situation but I don't see that happening because I can't imagine anyone being able to federate the current topology.

3) Is there any more minimal change to fix the bug? This seems to mix up some major refactoring with addressing a bug.

Answer: There maybe something that gets you over this in some way. But I am surprised this has ever worked. I've never looked at the broker before last week and was surprised with the topology.  All the fix would do is kill off many NEVER used exchanges that are created. It seems that the current addressing causes unused exchanges to be created too. Any fix would need to address that and that means changing the addressing anyway. (Much like I have done)

4) We can't use a static exchange name. The code gets shared among multiple projects. If they're all sharing the same exchange, they will conflict when they use the same topics, right?

Answer: Actually you can. The exchange is just an artifact of a pre-AMQP 1.0 world.  The current addressing can fully support this. The exchange name becomes a namespace inside of this addressing scheme that ought to exclude clashes. 


What my concern is this:
A. I have managed to get this pass the tests. But do the tests confirm it doesn't cause issues with '4' above?

B. I (well watched a colleague) have tested this in lab with a couple of instances and it seemed to work.  But is that a sufficient test along with A?

C. I don't know how you could possible scale the current situation. Besides being broken it is also not scalable even if we quick-fixed it in my opinion. The schema doesn't lend itself very well to federation.  A more controllable addressing schema allows us to scale it with Qpid.Federation becomes easier mainly because addressing is more AMQP 1.0.

D. The Openstack docs claim use of AMQP.  As AMQP 1.0 is the only ratified AMQP can we continue to do that with an addressing mechanism that is fundamentally pre-AMQP 1.0? Exposing exchanges etc. is really not very AMQP anymore.  The new addressing that I am using, though supporting the pre-AMQP 1.0 artifacts like exchanges, allows us to transition to AMQP 1.0 very very easily. 

So I agree with you all that does seem like a big change. If the flag setting that Russell mentioned in some thread holds true then perhaps for this release that seems to be less risk  (though I worry the risk is more by leaving the topology the way it is. 

I will provide some historical background to why the addressing is as it today. It seemed to make sense at the time."}, {'account_id': 2349, 'date': '2013-06-11 18:50:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Historical background to current addressing schema:

1. Openstack supports "AMQP" and had a current implementation for the nova/rpc called kombu. This kombu, I'll call it a driver, supported RabbitMQ.

2. The Apache Qpid project were eager to provide a similar driver that would map the RPC layer to Qpid.

3. The Apache Qpid project had already started transforming it's client API with a empahsis on future AMQP 1.0 support. So APIs such as exchangeDeclare etc., which expose artifacts like exchanges and queues and bindings, were deprecated. These were replaced with simplier Senders and Receivers.

4. In order to map Senders and Receivers to the existing exchange/queue/binding based broker, qpidd, there was an addressing mechanism that allowed us to create AMQP 1.0 based artifacts, nodes and queues, to existing exchanges, and queues where appropriate.  Note node != exchange. A node can be a qpidd queue artifact.

5. At the time writing impl_qpid.py - the Nova RPC "driver" for Qpid it was deemed best to try and map as best we could the way kombu worked.  So with the dynamic creation of exchanges and queues, sometimes at the same time, it led to elaborate and complex addressing.

6. It would seem that this mapping was a mistake, IMO. It may already have had the leaky bug in it. A later change with tried to do some clever reuse with json seems to have added another bug - i.e. a "type: topic" change was added but seems to be applied at the wrong scope in the address. hence duplicate types are in the address. This is a bug and almost certainly is causing more issues. However I suspect the original addressing was still a problem 

So I think that how we got here.  I may be misguided or perhaps only slightly off. After all I'm sticking my nose in again a long time after impl_qpid.py was introduced (18 months?). So I apologize for not being more involved in testing and examining the behavior sooner.  

I I had known then what I know now about the way things are used I believe I would NOT have supported the direct kombu to qpid mapping. But at the time it seemed to make the most sense. Just keep things kinda the way they are.  

Which is my motivation for trying to have a more substantial change now. 

It appears to work:  1) jenkins tests passed - I changed the expected addresses in the test_qpid.py. And examination of a Openstack env in the lab seems to bear out that it is working. Is there a more substantial test env we can try this out in? Or is jenkins enough?'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-06-11 19:12:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

The jenkins tests here are just basic unit tests, not any of the functional tests that run once the code gets integrated into another project.  If you want to see the rest of the tests run, you can put up a WIP change against nova.'}, {'account_id': 4912, 'date': '2013-06-12 00:08:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'm not sure where federation fits in the openstack scaling paradigm beyond where cells currently is, but I am interested to hear your thoughts. Maybe we could discuss this on the ML where we could get input from a broader audience?

I think as is there needs to be some more design around this, a BP that clearly describes the use case and the direction that you want to take.  Maybe I am going overkill on this but I really feel like that would help.

Changing things just be because it fits better with the current AMQP paradigm doesnt seem like a great reason. There probably are good reasons to change but they need to be better understood IMO before this should merge."}, {'account_id': 2349, 'date': '2013-06-12 00:11:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

It's not the only reason. See above. I feel the current approach is broken. Just wasn't noticed much until recently."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-19 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-19 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-07-19 16:10:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

With regards to the backwards compat concern, we could consider adding a new driver name for this like 'impl_qpid2' and it would implement the new scheme while we retain support for the old scheme

Obviously we wouldn't completely copy the code - we'd share as much as possible"}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2013-08-28 16:15:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Restored'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-08-28 16:31:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I asked for this to be reopened.  I plan to update it shortly.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-08-28 17:22:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-08-28 17:22:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: No score

New patchset patch-id matches previous patchset, but commit message has changed.'}, {'account_id': 2349, 'date': '2013-08-28 17:52:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Please do the following to the address for consumers and producers for topology 2.

Add to the current topic and fanout addresses for consumers:
'amq.topic/'

e.g. amq.topic/topic/%s
     amq.topic/fanout/%s 

I'm assuming that uses will add the '/' or '.' delimiters inside their own %s.

For direct I now think we should use the following schema:

amq.direct/%

i.e. you need to add 'amq.' on front of direct for the consumers.

The producers will need to change accordingly.

amq.topic/topic/%s for topic
amq.topic/fanout/%s for fanout 
amq.direct/%s for direct

Tests will need to change.

We could also get rid of the addr_opts (or set to empty map) for topology 2, since it doesn;t do anything different from default (makes it simpler to read an understand the addresses)"}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-08-28 18:32:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-08-28 18:35:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

'}, {'created': '2013-08-28 17:22:01.000000000', 'message': "Support a new qpid topology

There has been a bug open for a while pointing out that the way we
create fanout exchanges with qpid results in leaking exchanges since
qpid doesn't support auto-deleting exchanges.  This was somewhat
mitigated by change to use a single reply queue.  This meant we created
far fewer direct exchanges, but the problem persists anyway.

A Qpid expert, William Henry, originally proposed a change to address
this issue.  Unfortunately, it wasn't backwards compatible with existing
installations.  This patch takes the same approach, but makes it
optional and off by default.  This will allow a migration period.

As a really nice side effect, the Qpid experts have told us that this
change will also allow us to use Qpid broker federation to provide HA.

Closes-bug: #1178375
Co-authored-by: William Henry <whenry@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I09b8317c0d8a298237beeb3105f2b90cb13933d8

commit_message:
Support a new qpid topology

There has been a bug open for a while pointing out that the way we
create direct exchanges with qpid results in leaking exchanges since
qpid doesn't support auto-deleting exchanges.  This was somewhat
mitigated by change to use a single reply queue.  This meant we created
far fewer direct exchanges, but the problem persists anyway.

A Qpid expert, William Henry, originally proposed a change to address
this issue.  Unfortunately, it wasn't backwards compatible with existing
installations.  This patch takes the same approach, but makes it
optional and off by default.  This will allow a migration period.

As a really nice side effect, the Qpid experts have told us that this
change will also allow us to use Qpid broker federation to provide HA.

DocImpact
Closes-bug: #1178375
Co-authored-by: William Henry <whenry@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I09b8317c0d8a298237beeb3105f2b90cb13933d8

[{'created': '2013-07-09 18:34:32.000000000', 'message': 'Introduces Basic Report and Model

Introduces the classes for basic reports and the base data model
class to hold data for the report.  A basic report is composed of
sections, each of which has a generator (which produces the model)
and a view (which converts the model into a given representation).
Models may have an associated view, as well, to allow for sub-models
to have specific views attached to them.  This is the first part
of the Guru Meditation Report Framework.

commit_message:
Introduces Basic Report and Model

Introduces the classes for basic reports and the base data model
class to hold data for the report.  A basic report is composed of
sections, each of which has a generator (which produces the model)
and a view (which converts the model into a given representation).
Models may have an associated view, as well, to allow for sub-models
to have specific views attached to them.  This is the first part
of the Guru Meditation Report Framework.

Change-Id: Ic3ad1fd595da8742b5e7d4349a23132fc560f292
Implements: bp guru-meditation-report

heat-engine.conf, heat-api.conf, heat-api-cfn.conf, heat-api-cw.conf

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-30 17:48:19.000000000', 'message': 'OAuth authorizing user should propose roles to delegate

Currently in the oauth1 extension the consumer specifies roles
instead of delegator. This is a design fault that should be fixed
by having the authorizing user provide a set of roles (ids)
during the authorize request token phase.

fixes bug: #1216408

Change-Id: I08e803c7e046d4a2436c08535e2344ee654de889
'}]
commit_message:
OAuth authorizing user should propose roles to delegate

Currently in the oauth1 extension the consumer specifies roles
instead of delegator. This is a design fault that should be fixed
by having the authorizing user provide a set of roles (ids)
during the authorize request token phase.

fixes bug: #1216408

Change-Id: I08e803c7e046d4a2436c08535e2344ee654de889

commit_message:
Removed instance reset_password from python-troveclient

The reset_password operation no longer exists and needs to be removed
from python-troveclient.

Change-Id: Ic162ef6deb86716fa12fa5541699f602c246563e
Fixes: bug 1199507

commit_message:
Fix empty metadata issue of instance

Based on current implement, some metadata can't be extracted by
pollster, such as architecture, reservation_id, ephemeral_gb, etc.
This patch will try to get those metadata if we can and remove
those metadata what can't be pulled by pollster.

Fixes bug 1202749

Change-Id: I1f08c4eaa1cfacb612097cd0e90629d682f8acc9

commit_message:
XenAPI: More operations with LVM-based SRs

Some operations require Files-based SRs (ext3/NFS) - such as resize
and VHD download.  However, if using 3-part images or RAW then most
operations can be successful with this simple fix.

Fixes bug 1162382

Change-Id: Ia3d1c64871d78ab1bf6e197edaeee170d2b5dea8

commit_message:
XenAPI: make_partition fixes for Dom0

When running in dom0, the calls to parted fail to re-read the partition
table so we have to use kpartx to read it specifically.

The failure to re-read the partition table also means that the exit code
is non-0.

Implements blueprint xenserver-core

Change-Id: I56ca25874d6491b0ed70e5efd477254bfe47294d

[{'created': '2013-08-30 10:33:51.000000000', 'message': 'Remove localhost references from tests

Using localhost in dummy URLs is a bad idea, because if you get
your mocking slightly wrong, some tests try to connect to the
services running in your local test environment.

Change-Id: I5550c397230f94740c63e6cab30ac35b3ae85297
'}]
commit_message:
Remove localhost references from tests

Using localhost in dummy URLs is a bad idea, because if you get
your mocking slightly wrong, some tests try to connect to the
services running in your local test environment.

Change-Id: I5550c397230f94740c63e6cab30ac35b3ae85297

commit_message:
Fix and gate on H302 (import only modules)

H302 is already part of the OpenStack style guide, and we only had a few
violations.  This fixes and gates on H302, so there is one less thing
for a reviewer to worry about.

gettext import line is ignored using hacking 0.7's import_exceptions
option.

Reason for import only modules 'The namespace management convention is
simple. The source of each identifier is indicated in a consistent way;
x.Obj says that object Obj is defined in module x.'
http://google-styleguide.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/pyguide.html

Change-Id: I53e8039f1dd2ebf8ab5fcf5a561feb3ca3363107

'}, {'account_id': 2265, 'date': '2013-08-10 20:02:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi Dan,

The code of the patch looks good, but it seems like exposing both the individual auth params (url/protocol/port) as well as the auth_uri is a but confusing to the end user (it's really easy to supply one, and forget the other, in which case, you may have unexpected failures that are hard to track down)

I have a few questions:

1. Why not use the individual parameters to construct the URL?

2. What if the user supplies both the individual auth parameters as well as this one? Which values are used for what purpose?

3. Should we deprecate the individual auth parameters and have the users supply the entire auth_uri?

4. Should we warn the user if they don't supply a auth_host, but do not update auth_uri?"}, {'account_id': 2265, 'date': '2013-08-10 20:03:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

sorry, the #4 should have been:

4. Should we warn the user if they supply an auth_host, but do not update auth_uri?'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-08-13 14:07:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

bodepd:

This patch is motivated by the following upstream keystoneclient bug/change:

https://bugs.launchpad.net/python-keystoneclient/+bug/1207517
https://github.com/openstack/python-keystoneclient/commit/734ef6eb83a9d9d49c181018ba63e45dbcfa1c90

To answer your questions:

1) We could. Keystoneclient is not longer attempting to do this and it is plausible that an end user might want to create a custom version anyway.

2) From the ticket: If an auth_uri is not configured, then auth_token falls back on the admin API endpoint, and provides this to clients... who may not have visibility of the admin endpoint, much less be able to properly authenticate against it.

3) No. The individual auth params are still required.

4) I don't think so.

----

In this regard I sort of thing following the keystoneclient defaults is a good idea here..."}, {'account_id': 2265, 'date': '2013-08-13 17:42:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

dprince: thanks for that information. I wanted to run one other possible implementation by you:

what if by default instead of using an entirely different string that defaults to localhost, we instead compose it based on the parts already passed in:

    ....
     $auth_host        = '127.0.0.1',
     $auth_port        = 35357,
     $auth_protocol  = 'http',
     $auth_uri          = false,
    ....

     if ! $auth_url {
        $auth_uri = "${auth_protocol}:://${auth_host}:5000"
     }

I know it requires a little bit more code, but it protects against my concern that by default users are going to not understand they have to set both.'}, {'account_id': 7156, 'date': '2013-08-13 21:47:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I agree with Dan Bode. If auth_uri isn't provided, there should be a way to compute the value from other provided parameters just like the mentioned patch is doing."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-08-15 01:12:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

bodepd: I like that fine. Will fix it up in the incoming patch...'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-08-22 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-08-22 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

commit_message:
Add default auth_uri setting for auth token.

The latest keystoneclient code now gives a Warning if auth_uri
isn't explicitly specified.

Change-Id: I0feb52f7a9140ea750254f80b6a3e6855b25f1d3

[{'created': '2013-08-30 16:30:10.000000000', 'message': 'Add Ironic database creation to boot-stack

This patch will add creation and db-sync of Ironic database if Ironic
environment is found. This will allow developers to include the Ironic
element in the under-cloud image and deploy it from the seed vm for
development work and integration testing.

Change-Id: I6504c2eddefded3b7751b451109ee3bbfc6101a9
Authored-by: Chris Krelle <nobodycam@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Add Ironic database creation to boot-stack

This patch will add creation and db-sync of Ironic database if Ironic
environment is found. This will allow developers to include the Ironic
element in the under-cloud image and deploy it from the seed vm for
development work and integration testing.

Change-Id: I6504c2eddefded3b7751b451109ee3bbfc6101a9
Authored-by: Chris Krelle <nobodycam@gmail.com>

This LGTM overall, and I'd love for us to have early access to this.

However, I want the commit message for this to be more clear that the intent is to bring in a *verbatim* copy of the oslo.cache rather than for us to *maintain* a fork. That implies to me that 1) we're going to patch it locally at some point and/or 2) that this patchset already includes modifications to oslo.cache.

Thanks! :)"}, {'account_id': 6427, 'date': '2013-08-29 20:24:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rebased'}, {'account_id': 6944, 'date': '2013-08-29 20:24:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

commit_message:
chore: Track the up-and-coming oslo.cache module

While we wait for oslo.cache to land, I'd like to maintain a
verbatim copy under marconi.common so that we can start using
it immediately.

When oslo.cache is approved upstream, this copy of the code
will go away and we will add cache to marconi's
openstack-commong.conf

Change-Id: I608a2891ca06caec47ce18eda4edacd07bec40e9

commit_message:
XenAPI: SR location should default to location stored in PBD

This value must be read from the PBD as it may change for different
installations.  The existing default is preserved as a fallback
for the cases where a PBD path is not set.

Implements blueprint xenserver-core

Change-Id: I055ebe8d7d79f238b0b9565277acac945bbe12e1

commit_message:
XenAPI: Generic Fake.get_all_records_where implementation

Tests were incorrectly passing due to bad implementations.

Note that link to xenserver-core blueprint is due to patch following this
change

Implements blueprint xenserver-core

subject: xenapi: agent not inject ssh-key if cloud-init

same comment as the last rev"}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-08-27 10:36:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

Russell that key about cloud-init is now used for both ssh and file injection that happens during the boot process (you can still inject files using the agent, after the boot process, as cloud-init doesn't replace it).

I could add two image flags here:
xenapi_disable_agent_ssh
xenapi_disable_file_injection_during_boot

But it seems (marginally) better to have a single flag that is more descriptive of the image, highlighting when cloud-init is present.

We already have a flag to report if the agent is installed or not, this is really just the other side of the coin, so we can have any combination of the agent, cloud-init, or both, or none, and do roughly the right thing during the transition period.

The above flag is also planned to be used for things like enabling/disabling the RAX UI to show up "User Data" fields, and similar things.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-08-28 11:52:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-28 13:00:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
xenapi: agent not inject ssh-key if cloud-init

It is possible to have an image with both the xenapi agent and
cloud-init present, or an alternative agent that makes use of metadata
to configure a server.

To ensure the agent will not clash with the ssh key and file injection
of the agent, I have added image properties so we can disable these
agent operations on a per image basis.

The image properties this new code looks for are:
xenapi_skip_agent_inject_ssh=true
xenapi_skip_agent_inject_files_at_boot=true

DocImpact
Part of blueprint xenapi-guest-agent-cloud-init-interop
Change-Id: I416ade49663208769571fe0c9cf22c8fc1360244

[{'created': '2013-08-28 16:15:59.000000000', 'message': 'Extend JobBinary REST api to allow retrieval of raw data.

Return a job binary as a Python escaped string.  This addition
will allow JobOrigin objects to refer to job binaries stored in
the savanna database by URL without special cases.

Change-Id: Iaf1f8cd92aa4659e6b5995089bfc89104d1b5da5
'}, {'created': '2013-08-28 16:22:25.000000000', 'message': 'Extend JobBinary REST api to allow retrieval of raw data

Return a job binary as a Python escaped string. This encoding
is the same form the data takes in the job_binary_create() REST
API method when a binary is uploaded via http.  This addition
will allow JobOrigin objects to refer to job binaries stored in
the savanna database by URL without special cases.

Change-Id: Iaf1f8cd92aa4659e6b5995089bfc89104d1b5da5
'}, {'created': '2013-08-28 19:39:29.000000000', 'message': 'Extend JobBinary REST api to allow retrieval of raw data

Change-Id: Iaf1f8cd92aa4659e6b5995089bfc89104d1b5da5
'}, {'created': '2013-08-29 15:45:20.000000000', 'message': 'Extend JobBinary REST api to allow retrieval of raw data

Change-Id: Iaf1f8cd92aa4659e6b5995089bfc89104d1b5da5
'}]
commit_message:
Extend JobBinary REST api to allow retrieval of raw data

Return job binary data as raw bytes.  This addition will allow
JobOrigin objects to refer to job binaries stored in the
savanna database by URL without special cases.

Change-Id: Iaf1f8cd92aa4659e6b5995089bfc89104d1b5da5

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-28 06:45:45.000000000', 'message': 'Neutron support

Added configurations:
* use_neutron
* neutron_management_network

Implements blueprint add-neutron-support

Change-Id: If6e79327ab14bbc813175396cd7287c2a29149b0
'}, {'created': '2013-08-28 08:33:55.000000000', 'message': "Neutron support

Added configurations:
* use_neutron
* neutron_management_network

If Neutron is enabled, management network id is
passed as a parameter, when instances are being
launched.

Instance's internal and management IPs are equal and
point to the first IP in a list of a specified
management network.

Implements blueprint add-neutron-support

Change-Id: If6e79327ab14bbc813175396cd7287c2a29149b0
"}, {'created': '2013-08-28 11:46:51.000000000', 'message': "Neutron support

Added configurations:
* use_neutron

If Neutron is enabled, management network id is
passed as a parameter, when instances are being
launched.

Instance's internal and management IPs are equal and

commit_message:
Neutron support

Added configurations:
* use_neutron

If Neutron is enabled, management network id is
passed as a parameter, when instances are being
launched.

Instance's internal and management IPs are equal and
point to the first IP in a list of a specified
management network.

Model classes for Cluster and Cluster Template updated.

Implements blueprint add-neutron-support

Change-Id: If6e79327ab14bbc813175396cd7287c2a29149b0

commit_message:
Oozie + MySQL configuration

* oozie-site.xml MySQL configuration
* MySQL starts on oozie node group
* MySQL starts if MySQL is enabled by config
* Oozie DB schema creating in MySQL
* Applying multiple general configs
* Added test for general configs

Implements blueprint edp-oozie-for-vanilla-plugin

Change-Id: I77342be5523f8584a5c6ba0d9fa2794d2702d27d

commit_message:
Neutron support

Network dropdown added.

To enable support add
"SAVANNA_USE_NEUTRON = True" to local_setting.py

Partially implements blueprint add-neutron-support

Change-Id: I88c795ef6d35caf5fd1780acb3b7dbf1333337af

While this isn't a perfect solution for what we need for per test specific debugging info I think that it's a good enough start to build off of.

Using the print doesn't work outside the test level because the fixture for capturing stdout and stderr is run in setUp() so things printed from setUpClass() won't get captured.

While using log to capture this information and print it out per test failing will work and not leak stdout.(it'll just go to the log file) this still won't capture from setUpClass()."}, {'account_id': 5586, 'date': '2013-08-30 09:09:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

commit_message:
per test_method logging

Using the FakeLogger/LoggerFixture fixture in order to capture the
per test method logs.

The per test method log capturing visible in the console on error or
failure.

The normal logging is preserved and only the INFO level log is
captured.

Change-Id: Id42f79bd3bcaba9aba57f4c0b8a373f33b8cd6bd

commit_message:
Either external AD or internal one is required for MS SQL Cluster.

Change-Id: Idde251b1c7b1a31cadb5f416f753e365fe572961
Fixes: bug MRN-909.

commit_message:
Fix usage of classmethod in various places

The decorator @classmethod isn't always correctly used in the code base,
this patches fixes some places where it was not used correctly.

Change-Id: Ifd4113b693889de0becc37854f4c62faf2fdab11

commit_message:
powervm: make start_lpar timeout

This patch makes the start_lpar method timeout like the stop_lpar
method.

Change-Id: I111ed7ee80f7a9e786d8cb8b02747b5187120858

commit_message:
Fix bulk networks/ports/subnet creation

Request/Response for bulk networks/ports/subnets creation were missing
I have added xml and json request/response bodies for these.

Fixes LP bug #1213890

It is, openstack-arch-grizzly-v1.graffle and openstack-arch-grizzly-v1.zip are in /common/figures. But sometimes people don't know that and I think a comment in the source nearest the figure is a nice convention. I could change it to a link to raw.github if you think that's better than what's in this patch."}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2013-08-29 14:23:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I definitely like the idea of annotating the XML with the location of the original files that were used to generate the image, but I do think the annotation should include the location inside of the repo. This would help authors figure out which file they need to change and commit if they want to alter a figure.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2013-08-29 14:47:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

It's a comment, so people will only see it if they look at the source. subject: powervm: revert driver to pass for plug_vifs
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 1653, 'name': 'garyk', 'email': 'gkotton@vmware.com', 'username': 'garyk'}, {'_account_id': 1849, 'name': 'Joe Gordon', 'email': 'joe.gordon0@gmail.com', 'username': 'jogo'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 5292, 'name': 'Christopher Yeoh', 'email': 'cbkyeoh@gmail.com', 'username': 'cyeoh-0'}, {'_account_id': 6873, 'name': 'Matt Riedemann', 'email': 'mriedem.os@gmail.com', 'username': 'mriedem'}, {'_account_id': 7069, 'name': 'Joshua Hesketh', 'email': 'josh@nitrotech.org', 'username': 'jhesketh'}, {'_account_id': 7282, 'name': 'Qing Xin Meng', 'email': 'mengqxqx@cn.ibm.com', 'username': 'mengqxqx'}]

'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-08-28 07:02:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 7069, 'date': '2013-08-28 08:03:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

It would be nice if all the methods acted the same. Perhaps we should handle the NotImplementedError and make all the drivers raise it. Otherwise it'd be nice if this patch at least makes all of them report the same log message."}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-08-28 08:55:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

If I recall correctly, and may be mistaken here, the plug vifs is only supported when the network implementation is Neutron. This is something that does not work with traditional Nova networking.
I would like to add VMware support for this in the I series (it was just too late in the game to do this for H).
Are people actually using this feature or is it experimental?'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2013-08-28 13:30:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Joshua, I don't want to change the other unimplemented powervm driver methods to pass because that causes a different bug when running tempest with the powervm driver (see change Ieaf256a5c0f54804686318d6cbd5877a5003c9eb).

From what I found, the other virt drivers that don't implement plug_vifs simply pass also. The hyper-v driver logs a message but the vmware driver doesn't:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/virt/hyperv/driver.py#L151

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/virt/vmwareapi/vmops.py#L1332

As for catching NotImplementedError in the compute.manager, I brought that up yesterday in IRC and Joe Gordon though it'd be best to simply change the powervm driver back to doing a pass on the method for now since that's what it was already doing before my change.

Given how close we are to the end of havana, I'd rather get the short term issue fixed and then work on longer term changes across the virt drivers in Icehouse, something Joe and I talked about in IRC yesterday.  As part of that, see bug 1209421."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2013-08-28 13:31:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Gary, from what I see in compute.manager, driver.plug_vifs is called on each instance on a host when the host is initialized, regardless of network implementation. Having said that, I don't know the history or intent behind plug_vifs."}, {'account_id': 7069, 'date': '2013-08-29 04:39:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Hi Matt,

Thanks for your explanation. I'm happy with that given the release timing.

Nice work :-)

This is you:
http://openstackreactions.enovance.com/2013/08/how-i-feel-when-a-1-turns-into-a-1-after-explanation/"}, {'account_id': 7282, 'date': '2013-08-29 08:48:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-08-29 18:33:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

LGTM, If there isn't a bug open to change the behavior of the other drivers to NotRaised it may be worth doing say, as I think that is a better behavior."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2013-08-29 20:08:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Joe, I opened bug 1218593 for the other cleanup.'}, {'account_id': 5292, 'date': '2013-08-30 10:04:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-30 10:04:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

Change Ieaf256a5c0f54804686318d6cbd5877a5003c9eb made the powervm driver
plug_vifs method raise NotImplementedError rather than pass, which is
what the hyper-v and vmware drivers do for plug_vifs. This results in
the compute manager failing to init the host because it's not catching
NotImplementedError from driver.plug_vifs.

This patch simply changes the powervm driver plug_vifs method back to
the old behavior (pass), but at least logs a debug message this time.

Closes-Bug: #1217586

Change-Id: Iafe87cbb9b3cf728a47cb9cc43151798fcbb780f
"}]
commit_message:
powervm: revert driver to pass for plug_vifs

Change Ieaf256a5c0f54804686318d6cbd5877a5003c9eb made the powervm driver
plug_vifs method raise NotImplementedError rather than pass, which is
what the hyper-v and vmware drivers do for plug_vifs. This results in
the compute manager failing to init the host because it's not catching
NotImplementedError from driver.plug_vifs.

This patch simply changes the powervm driver plug_vifs method back to
the old behavior (pass), but at least logs a debug message this time.

Closes-Bug: #1217586

Change-Id: Iafe87cbb9b3cf728a47cb9cc43151798fcbb780f

commit_message:
Make HostManager singleton

Currently there is no mechanism to maintain/synchronize more then 1
HostManager(HostState) in the system.
In order to support multiple active schedulers this class has to be a
singleton, this way each scheduler instance will hold a reference to the
same HostManager.

Required for implementation of blueprint multiple-scheduler-drivers.

Change-Id: I7d7d24d8e716ae9db16e4951b202614ebfdd7d8c

In Patch 7 made the following modifications:

1. For creating a volume in the inventory was picking any host and trying to create under it. If the host does not have datastore space to accomodate then I was failing the operation without retying on other hosts. Made modifications to try on all the hosts till we find a datastore that can satisfy volume size.

2. Retrying copy_backing in case folder already exists on the datastore due to previous failed attempt. This was a comment from jgriffith, which I realized now. The method now overwrites the folder by deleting the existing files.'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2013-08-21 14:57:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

'}, {'created': '2013-08-13 10:09:58.000000000', 'message': "Implements APIs for VMDK driver

- Implemented APIs: create_volume, delete_volume, initialize_connection
- Modified etc/cinder/cinder.conf.sample adding details for the driver
- Added suds dependency in requirements.txt and cinder.egg-info/requires.txt
- create_volume: does no work. Volume's backing is created lazily
- delete_volume: delete backing if present
- initialize_connection: if backing, not present, create backing, else
  provide backing details to nova to perform attach
  Nova BP/vmware-nova-cinder-support
- Written appropriate unit tests
- Work item in BP/vmware-vmdk-cinder-driver

Implements: blueprint vmware-vmdk-cinder-driver

"}, {'created': '2013-08-19 11:06:45.000000000', 'message': "Implements APIs for VMDK driver

- Implemented APIs: create_volume, delete_volume, initialize_connection,
  create_snapthot, delete_snapshot, create_volume_from_snapshot,
  create_cloned_volume
- Modified etc/cinder/cinder.conf.sample adding details for the driver
- Added suds dependency in requirements.txt
- create_volume: does no work. Volume's backing is created lazily
- delete_volume: delete backing if present
- initialize_connection: if backing, not present, create backing, else
  provide backing details to nova to perform attach
  Nova BP/vmware-nova-cinder-support
- create_snapshot: Creates the snapshot of the backing
- delete_snapshot: Deletes the snapshot of the backing
- create_volume_from_snapshot: Creates a full/linked clone from the snapshot
  point in VC. In ESX, copies the VM backing files, registers and reverts to
  the appropriate snapshot point.
- create_cloned_volume: Creates a full/linked clone in VC. In ESX, copies the
  VM backing files and registers as a new backing.
- Written appropriate unit tests
- Work item in BP/vmware-vmdk-cinder-driver

Implements: blueprint vmware-vmdk-cinder-driver
Change-Id: Ib11f2878f8f656209d1ba5e2cbfadae1ac1999b4

commit_message:
Implements APIs for VMDK driver

- Implemented APIs: create_volume, delete_volume, initialize_connection,
  create_snapthot, delete_snapshot, create_volume_from_snapshot,
  create_cloned_volume
- Modified etc/cinder/cinder.conf.sample adding details for the driver
- Added suds dependency in requirements.txt
- create_volume: does no work. Volume's backing is created lazily
- delete_volume: delete backing if present
- initialize_connection: if backing, not present, create backing, else
  provide backing details to nova to perform attach
  Nova BP/vmware-nova-cinder-support
- create_snapshot: Creates the snapshot of the backing
- delete_snapshot: Deletes the snapshot of the backing
- create_volume_from_snapshot: Creates a full/linked clone from the snapshot
  point in VC. In ESX, copies the VM backing files, registers and reverts to
  the appropriate snapshot point.
- create_cloned_volume: Creates a full/linked clone in VC. In ESX, copies the
  VM backing files and registers as a new backing.
- Written appropriate unit tests
- Work item in BP/vmware-vmdk-cinder-driver

Implements: blueprint vmware-vmdk-cinder-driver
Change-Id: Ib11f2878f8f656209d1ba5e2cbfadae1ac1999b4

Adds tests for Heat

Tests and client methods for:
- template-show
- template-validate
- template-url-validate
- stack-list
- stack-show
- resource-list
- resource-show
- resource-metadata
- event-list
- event-show

Testing Neutron resources:
- network
- subnet
- router_interface

Testing server property:
- subnet_id

Change-Id: I47bb0dd653da51c9ff1d2ffe0b02c102cc0098d5

commit_message:
Add missing LH SAN driver features for Havana

The LeftHand driver did not support snapshot or extend volume.
The following features are part of the minimum driver features
that should be implemented in every cinder driver. This patch
adds the following missing features;
create snapshot
delete snapshot
create volume from snapshot
extend volume
It also fixes the DocStrings in the unit test so they pass the
checks.

Change-Id: Icda790fcddf4ea11782a8d6ec57b1e8f871eb167
Fixes: bug 1217118

'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2013-08-28 06:40:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

Hi Svetlana,

I may have misunderstood the purpose of using standardized unique constraint names, but I had thought that it was to avoid the kind of problems we saw in migrations on other projects (e.g. glance) due to the differing default UC names in mysql versus postgres.

Is that the motivation here?

If so, has this migration been tested against multiple DB engines (specifically both mysql and postgres)?

Clearly there's mysql-specific logic in the migration, so I'm wondering if it's expected to also work against say postgres out of the box or whether any special-casing for postgres would be required also?

Cheers,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 6507, 'date': '2013-08-28 08:11:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

Eoghan,
About motivation: for each version in each backend unique name can be generated by different way. So we can get situation when we use different code for getting constraint in different backend. It will be better to have one concept of naming unique constraints and we will sure that one piece of code can work on all supported backends. More then it can be difficult to get unique key without name .
This migrations had been tested in mysql and postgres dialects in local mode because there is no any check of migrations in different backend. Special logic in this migration for mysql has been found during running dbsync in local mode. There is no need in foreign keys clearing for postgres (it's also has been tested)."}, {'account_id': 6507, 'date': '2013-08-28 09:37:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-28 09:58:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Fix wrong UniqueConstraint name

Table `sourseassoc` has a conflicted with
OpenStack naming convention UniqueConstraint name.
Each UniqueConstraint should be named as
`uniq_table_name0column_first0column_second`.

bp: ceilometer-db-sync-models-with-migrations

Change-Id: Ic35a9351add9dd3ce014c938505e268e131112e8

commit_message:
Clean up metadata refresh unit test

The stack was not being fully created, because the calls to the mock
functions were not present for the second instance.

Fixes bug #1217829

(cherry picked from commit 0f6e437e889f4a8d7b7c197047a380b04803f3c8)
Conflicts:
	heat/tests/test_metadata_refresh.py

Change-Id: I894473533eb40133e4c22facbbee749a971cec89
