Closes-Bug: #1179526

source_lang mismatch between Horizon and OpenStack Hub projects
has been addressed and the soruce language is changed from en_US
to en. This commit updates .tx/config to catch up it.

Also adds an entry for djangojs.po translation which was added

'}]
commit_message:
Sync Transifex config with the source lang change in Transifex

Closes-Bug: #1179526

source_lang mismatch between Horizon and OpenStack Hub projects
has been addressed and the soruce language is changed from en_US
to en. This commit updates .tx/config to catch up it.

Also adds an entry for djangojs.po translation which was added
to Transifex recently.

Change-Id: I9a574b92a8396d2fda493d8dfa1261ddccc4ad02

commit_message:
Extra indexes cleanup

After all migrations database state has a difference with model state
in each dialect.

There is difference in models with database in indexes.
For some dialects indexes is skipped and for other extra indexes declared.

Dropped unique index:
- `source.id` for mysql.

Created index:
- `resource_user_id_project_id_key` for mysql and sqlite.

bp: ceilometer-db-sync-models-with-migrations

Change-Id: I1fbb6dcdf6c3c21075caeef5241f09122d5e34c1

[{'created': '2013-08-19 08:20:51.000000000', 'message': "Add pagination parameter to the base class of stroage

Put all parameters for pagination into class named pagination,
add this paramter to the interface of the database driver.
For now, the methods support pagination query include
get_resources, get_meters, get_alarms.

Pagination parameter includes the following members:
1) 'limit': maximum number of items to return.
2) 'marker_pair': attribute-value pair to identify the last
    item of the previous page.
3) 'sort_keys': array of attributes by which results
    should be sorted.
4) 'sort_dirs': per-column array of sort_dirs,
    corresponding to sort_keys.

It is part of bp/paginate-db-search.

Implements blueprint paginate-db-search

Change-Id: I6eedcd728427f4ab20f575aa10675822301fd472

commit_message:
Add pagination parameter to the database backends of storage

Put all parameters for pagination into class named pagination,
add this paramter to the interface of the database driver.
For now, the methods support pagination query include
get_resources, get_meters, get_alarms.
For get_samples function, because it has parameter limit now,
which should be include in pagination class, it is hard to
add the pagination query in this patch(it involves API codes).
We will add that in another patch.

Pagination parameter includes the following members:
1) 'limit': maximum number of items to return.
2) 'primary_sort_dir': sort direction of primary key.
2) 'marker_value': value of the primary key to identify the last
    item of the previous page.
3) 'sort_keys': array of attributes user pass in except the primary key.
4) 'sort_dirs': per-column array of sort_dirs, corresponding to sort_keys.

We update the prototype of sqlalchemy, hbase, mongodb
db2 and logging storage backend.
Pagination query for mongodb is merged already, we need to
reverse it first.

It is part of bp/paginate-db-search.

Implements blueprint paginate-db-search

Change-Id: I6eedcd728427f4ab20f575aa10675822301fd472

commit_message:
Base Alarm history persistence model

Provides the storage model and non-implemented hooks
into the storage drivers as a placeholder.

Partially implements bp alarm-audit-api

Change-Id: I950bef5f01e545982709bfb78a2364fb8d4def7b

subject: xenapi: Direct upload of images to swift
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 177, 'name': 'Alex Meade', 'email': 'mr.alex.meade@gmail.com', 'username': 'alex-meade'}, {'_account_id': 475, 'name': 'Rick Harris', 'email': 'rick.harris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'rconradharris'}, {'_account_id': 616, 'name': 'Mark Washenberger', 'email': 'mark.washenberger@markwash.net', 'username': 'markwash'}, {'_account_id': 782, 'name': 'John Garbutt', 'email': 'john@johngarbutt.com', 'username': 'johngarbutt'}, {'_account_id': 1561, 'name': 'Russell Bryant', 'email': 'rbryant@redhat.com', 'username': 'russellb'}, {'_account_id': 1849, 'name': 'Joe Gordon', 'email': 'joe.gordon0@gmail.com', 'username': 'jogo'}, {'_account_id': 2835, 'name': 'Brian Elliott', 'email': 'bdelliott@gmail.com', 'username': 'belliott'}, {'_account_id': 6735, 'name': 'Bob Ball', 'email': 'bob.ball@citrix.com', 'username': 'bob-ball'}, {'_account_id': 7802, 'name': 'Teran McKinney', 'email': 'teran.mckinney@rackspace.com', 'username': 'teran-mckinney'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-08-12 18:03:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

why is this xenapi only?'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-08-12 18:22:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Joe: 

There isn't really way way to do this in a hypervisor agnostic way at the moment since, for efficiency reasons, most of Xenapi's image-manipulation is done via Dom0 plugins.

In general, direct-upload-to-swift is a great idea since it avoids the glance bottleneck; so it would be a good idea to implement a similar solution for the other hypervisors. I'm assuming most of the other hypervisors upload using the compute-manager, so there's probably an opportunity for them to share much more code between them."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-12 18:43:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed.  For information on how to proceed, see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GerritJenkinsGithub#Test_Failures

- http://logs.openstack.org/81/41481/1/check/gate-nova-python26/b1e5918 : SUCCESS in 27m 21s
- http://logs.openstack.org/81/41481/1/check/gate-nova-python27/c8576b9 : SUCCESS in 13m 37s

"}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-08-12 20:45:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-12 21:31:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/81/41481/2/check/gate-nova-pep8/fe8d419 : SUCCESS in 5m 39s
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/81/41481/2/check/gate-nova-docs/22205a1/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 5m 26s
- http://logs.openstack.org/81/41481/2/check/gate-nova-python26/c8d16b4 : SUCCESS in 25m 13s

- http://logs.openstack.org/81/41481/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/9d6cfbd : SUCCESS in 44m 50s

- http://logs.openstack.org/81/41481/2/check/gate-nova-pylint/6281a4e : SUCCESS in 13m 08s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-08-12 21:58:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Why is glance the bottleneck, shouldn't that be fixed in glance?  

Also if there is no way to fix it I would prefer to see a general solution not a xen only solution."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-08-12 22:31:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Why is glance the bottleneck, shouldn't that be fixed in glance?

It's not a problem with Glance per se, more of a problem with the default image streaming path of Nova -> Glance -> Swift.

There's no real benefit to going through Glance and, when operating at really large scale, it becomes very difficult to have enough Glance servers available to satisfy the upload and download needs of a cluster.

It's much simpler and more efficient for Nova to talk to Swift directly and use Glance purely as an image-registry.

> Also if there is no way to fix it I would prefer to see a general solution not a xen only solution.

I agree that a general solution is better than virt-specific solutions, but in this case, the general solution, as far as I can tell won't work for Xen (b/c of how dom0 plugins are used for dealing with images).

With that in mind, we've implemented the feature for Xen which could be used a as model for others to use when in creating libvirt/hyperv/vmware compatible solutions."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-08-13 02:02:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

In that case this does not implement the linked BP, the BP doesn't say anything about xenapi only."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-08-13 04:25:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Joe: Good point, should probably be 'Partially implements bp nova-direct-image-upload'."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-08-13 04:43:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I also would prefer to see this patch lay the groundwork for a more general solution instead of just focus on the xenapi'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-08-13 06:19:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Joe:

I don't think we have enough experience with the other virt-drivers to help much in this regard (we're developing/testing/deploying exclusively with xenapi at the moment).

Maybe we can recruit some people more familiar with each virt-driver to implement similar solutions for each (possibly sharing code where it makes sense)?

That said, I think giving XenAPI operators the ability to have more reliable/scalable snapshots is worth merging as-is. 

Seeing this go in  for XenAPI might help motivate other developers more familar with say hyperv or libvirt to draw up similar plans.

Eventually, we might be able iterate towards sharing more code between the drivers for this feature; but given how different the drivers can be, that would be tricky to get right up-front."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-08-13 06:28:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

" I'm assuming most of the other hypervisors upload using the compute-manager, so there's probably an opportunity for them to share much more code between them."  Sounds like making this more general shouldn't be too hard, it seems like all other virt drivers would share the same code, and xenapi driver would share most of the code as well.


Also, shouldn't something like this live in the swift or glance clients?  

The part I am uncomfortable with is saying this is a problem but here is the xenapi only solution.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-08-13 15:30:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> " I'm assuming most of the other hypervisors upload using the compute-manager, so there's probably an opportunity for them to share much more code between them." Sounds like making this more general shouldn't be too hard, it seems like all other virt drivers would share the same code, and xenapi driver would share most of the code as well.

At a high-level, I think the other virt-drivers should be more similar; but what I don't know (and I don't think my team does either) are the details to make this work for the other drivers.

Getting spun on those so that we can implement this feature for them is probably going to be time-consuming and result in a less-than-ideal product (due to our inexperience there).

It'd make more sense for someone (or a group) who actually uses it, to implement the necessary code for the other drivers, a) so there are more people familiar with it and b) so people who will actually use it have some ownership/incentive to keep it working).

As it stands, if we wrote the libvirt-driver--the reality of the situation is--that would be a fire-and-forget operation; I probably wouldn't look at that code much again, since we don't use it.

> Also, shouldn't something like this live in the swift or glance clients?

I don't understand. All we want to do is use the existing swiftclient to upload the image directly into Swift from Nova.

Since the Xen Dom0 has a python 2.4 environment we can't use the current swiftclient directly since that's written to 2.6, so we have a modified version of it.

However, a separate make-dom0-plugins-2.6-compatible blueprint is being talked about, at least on our side, to address this now that newer versions of Xen can handle 2.6.

> The part I am uncomfortable with is saying this is a problem but here is the xenapi only solution.

But just to be clear, it *is* a problem (that's why we wrote the code :-).

But we're just not in a good position at the moment to solve it for the other drivers since we have no experience there.'}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2013-08-13 15:51:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@jogo I agree that the BP sets an incorrect expectation that the direct upload code would work with all virt drivers.

That being said, the intention is to provide a specific feature for xenapi users that solves a problem of image downloads bottlenecking through the glance-api servers.  

I'm not sure what a general purpose solution that works across all virt drivers would look like.  Surely there would have to be some implementation-specific code in each driver to handle moving the image efficiently.  (For example, the image transfer code for the xenapi solution has to run in a different process/vm altogether as a plugin.)

I think writing a solution for all drivers is out of scope for this review, but would be interested in your thoughts."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-08-13 17:22:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Do not merge

This is turning into more of a design discussion.  Can this move to openstack-dev?'}, {'account_id': 6735, 'date': '2013-08-13 17:34:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

In terms of the 2.4/2.6 question, XenServer Dom0 can easily have python2.6 installed along side 2.4 and specific plugins can use anything they like (just with a #! at the start) - so if we need swift to use 2.6 in dom0 then that's fine."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-08-13 17:54:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Bob:

Yeah, I think the concern is around making sure everyone has Python2.6 installed.

If we're cool with making that a requirement for this feature, then that would simplify things considerably in that we could drop the hacked-up version of swiftclient."}, {'account_id': 6735, 'date': '2013-08-13 18:01:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

In theory I'm happy to make 2.6 a requirement - I'd just want to make sure the method we use to select 2.6 in current XenServers will work with the next version of XenServer, which will ship with 2.6 by default."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-08-13 18:20:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Bob:

Yeah, I think on our end, we didn't want to be forced into rolling out 2.6 support into order to get this feature (that's a lot of machines to update).

The idea was to support 2.4, have a separate bp to add 2.6 support for all dom0 plugins, and then deprecate the 2.4 versions of everything.

That would give operators a transition period where they can roll out the necessary changes to all the machines."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-08-13 18:56:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I see two issues with this:


1) Expanding the plugins directory (related to py24 py26/py27 issue)
2) A new feature that all virt drivers would like to use, that is only loosely coupled with the actual drivers. And only implemented for one driver


While both these are issues are related, I would like to see both resolved before this being merged.  But at the very least I would like to see this implemented for the general case as well.

Having such divergent virt driver features is not a good thing, and I don't want to make it any worse then it is today."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-08-13 19:39:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> I see two issues with this:
> 1) Expanding the plugins directory (related to py24 py26/py27 issue)

I don't see why this is really a problem. It's expanding it for a useful optimization (by adding the uploader), and expanding it to add a 2.4 compliant swiftclient (to ease operators transition to 2.6).

Neither of those sounds like bad things. And one is just temporary.

> Having such divergent virt driver features is not a good thing, and I don't want to make it any worse then it is today.

I agree that divergent drivers are not ideal, but neither is requiring developers be experts in *all* virt-drivers. 

Do we as a community really expect developers implementing a optimization in xenapi to be familiar enough with hyperv to make a similar change? 

Similarly do we expect libvirt developers to be able to even *run* hyperv to test whether that change functionally works? I think the realistic answer here is, of course not!

That would be expecting too much. We know how difficult it is to get a change developed, unit-tested, functionally tested, and merged even when you know a driver through-and-through.

Requiring a person or team to do this across N virt-drivers seems like a deal-breaker for any non-trivial changes.

Rather I think we should have a more 'organic' process where virt-drivers 'grow' new features and optimizations and by watching the review queue, other virt-driver experts/owners try to mirror those same features with a goal of refactoring to share common code where possible.

(This also has the side benefit of allowing virt-drivers to try out approaches without having to commit to a massive effort of global/virt-driver-agnostic changes. Perhaps some of these optimizations die on the vine if they turn out not to be worth it, or for some reason are *much* harder in another virt-driver).

TL;DR lockstep feature parity will stifle innovation if that's a hard requirement, we need a more flexible, async way of adding features."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-08-13 20:16:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

two things:

1) lets move this discussion to the -dev mailing list.  Write up a short summery of what you are trying to do and send that out and I will respond with my comments on it.
2) I am not saying all virt drivers must support all the same features and to add a feature to one you must add it to all.  I am saying at least provide the general framework for others to use (especially when it sounds like all other virt drivers need just one implementation of this), all this stuff in the plugins directory is hardly code other virt drivers will use.  virt driver specific code should be just that, code that cannot be re-used by other drivers.  Much of this code sounds like it can be re-used (except for the funny py24 issue ...)'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-08-13 23:37:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Joe:

Yeah you and Russell are right that the high-level discussion is probably better suited for the ML.

Specific to this patch though:

> Much of this code sounds like it can be re-used (except for the funny py24 issue ...)

I'd love to see what exactly--inline comments would be appreciated here--could be reused with other drivers.

I'm just not seeing it. Most of the code is just implementation details around running `swift_client.put(image)` in dom0.

Other than the additional exceptions that this introduces, what else can be shared?"}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-08-15 19:25:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (3 inline comments)

When looking at the plugins dir, I noticed the plugins say they are for py26, which just makes me more confused.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-08-15 20:54:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-08-21 09:52:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I think the correct approach here is to use the standard swift client, by installing python 2.6 in dom0.

I think the plugin might have to be python 2.4, then shell out to the swift CLI that is python 2.6, but maybe it could be a python 2.6 plugin that calls swift directly, its not totally clear.

It is possible that we are missing a dependency in dom0 that can't be pulled in, but we should at least try that out. We can pull python 2.6 from EPEL, and easy_install_26 pip, then pip the rest should work.

In terms of divergence, this example implementation should help other virt drivers copy the functionality, however, we should build some consensus around this being a good idea.

I didn't spot the mail thread, I will try check that later."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-08-21 17:38:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

John:

Good points.

I've talked to some of the original developers and it seems like dependencies (not python2.6) were the main reasons why the hacked client was added.

I think once we address those, I think we'll be clear to use the native swiftclient.

I've back-burnered this a bit since it's not very time-sensitive (we've been holding this patch for a while, so a few more weeks/months won't kill us!).

When I get pack that upstream-direct-swift-plugin ticket, I'll send something out to the list."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-08-21 17:38:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Work In Progress

commit_message:
xenapi: Direct upload of images to swift

Added support for nova to upload images directly to object store
instead of uploading through glance when using Xen.

Implements bp nova-direct-image-upload
DocImpact

Change-Id: I820c91474c8a66e6722bd2617c75d463202687e1

commit_message:
Configure the ec2 credentials explicitly in tempest

There is fall back logic in tempest to get the credentials himself,
when it is missing, but it causes additional start up time.

It is annoying on test case development.

Long time ago it happened at setup_package() time, but now tempest
does not uses this function.

Change-Id: Ic44bfb727ac6aa3fa2596a68aca0b562a67ea91a

subject: Make test_version_flag handle package distributions
messages:
[{'account_id': 6683, 'date': '2013-08-22 15:21:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I see this as issue, and good patch, but I'm not really sure about what's the correct behavior.

Why should 'version' and '--version' report different versions in first place? I think they should do the same thing, unless documented otherwise ... https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=952811

And if they should serve different purpose, how/where it's decided which purpose will serve each of them?"}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2013-08-22 15:54:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Pavel, I'm not really sure either, but from searching around my development venv I'm seeming to find that 'version' is getting the package version via numpy and --version is getting the version of the python package for nova from distutils via optparser. With devstack, there are no distribution packages so numpy wouldn't find anything, devstack gets everything via github or pypi I think."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2013-08-22 16:00:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

But numpy doesn't make much sense on the system where I'm reproducing this because I don't have numpy installed apparently.  And optparse is part of the logilab package which I do have installed (but not sure what's pulling it in)."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-08-30 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-22 14:28:35.000000000', 'message': 'Make test_version_flag handle package distributions

The test_version_flag test case assumes that "nova-manage --version"
will equal "nova-manage version" which may be the case with devstack but
is not necessarily the case when using a different distribution, like
RPMs with CentOS or RHEL.  The test case should just make sure that
"nova-manage --version" is a subset of "nova-manage version".

For example:

[root@ip9-12-17-44 ~]# nova-manage version
2013.2-201308212212.el6
[root@ip9-12-17-44 ~]# nova-manage --version
2013.2

Closes-Bug: #1214781

Change-Id: I07298b6398c79322fca8b349d026a1c09ce4a77b
'}]
commit_message:
Make test_version_flag handle package distributions

The test_version_flag test case assumes that "nova-manage --version"
will equal "nova-manage version" which may be the case with devstack but
is not necessarily the case when using a different distribution, like
RPMs with CentOS or RHEL.  The test case should just make sure that
"nova-manage --version" is a subset of "nova-manage version".

For example:

[root@ip9-12-17-44 ~]# nova-manage version
2013.2-201308212212.el6
[root@ip9-12-17-44 ~]# nova-manage --version
2013.2

Closes-Bug: #1214781

Change-Id: I07298b6398c79322fca8b349d026a1c09ce4a77b

New patchset patch-id matches previous patchset, but commit message has changed.'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-08-12 12:24:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Libvirt will also do CPU compatibility checking upon migration. If OpenStack is refusing a migration request, which libvirt would in turn allow, then Nova is simply broken. Adding a config option to turn off the CPU checks is not the right way to deal with this. Either nova should be fixed so that its checks are actually correct, or its checks be removed entirely, delegating to libvirt."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-12 12:41:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Add a RPC API to get a guest info from hypervisor

If libvirt is used, using this RPC API to get the xml describtion
of an instance from the libvirtd hosts the instance. Instead of the
source host CPU, comparing the instance CPU with destination host
CPU by using the xml describtion.

Return the exact reason in admin_actions API if the instance CPU
is incompatible with the dest host CPU.

Fixes bug #1082414

Co-authored-by: Takashi Natsume <natsume.takashi@lab.ntt.co.jp>
Change-Id: I65f505fec64c65d2641d2bfd940cde44bcd83a77

commit_message:
Add support for local XenAPI connection

Detects if we're running in dom0 and sets the connection URL
to be a recognisable string
Running as a local XenAPI connection also means we have to
treat the networking differently

Change-Id: Iec2b4fda874a8d1a6134cf1d3ea7a6f54d79bdcc

commit_message:
Avoid using GREENDNS due to dnspython

If dnspython is present in your environment then
eventlet monkeypatches socket.getaddrinfo() with an implementation
which doesn't work for IPv6. To turn this off you need to set an
environment variable before you do the import.

Resolves bug 1164822

Change-Id: I4aa3d40d0f8d0f125c3a89c4ba062ad0d13f1c55

We have to think about people using master and having the format_token taken from under their feet. How hard would it be for us to deprecate the token_format parameter? commit_message:
Updates Keystone Token Support

Previously, Grizzly used the [signing] section of keystone.conf
to manage the format [UUID|PKI] of auth tokens.

In Havana, the [signing] section of keystone.conf has been
deprecated in favor of provider in the [token] section:

  https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/master/etc/keystone.conf.sample#L170-L173

The token_format parameter has been replaced by the token_provider
parameter, which defaults to keystone.token.providers.pki.Provider
for backwards compatibility and to use PKI-based tokens.

Change-Id: Ie3a82a8e26c5504314fdaf16224741e936192aab

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-23 02:35:04.000000000', 'message': "Rename all OS:: resource types with registry mapping

This change is to demonstrate a possible new naming scheme
for native OpenStack resource types. It implements a strawman
naming scheme and provides global environment registry mappings
so that any template using an old name should continue to work
indefinitely.

The justification for this scheme is as follows:
1. All lower case, as this is easier to type and easier to read
   for non-native english readers
2. Top level namespace is 'os' for OpenStack
3. Second level namespace should be taken from the keystone catalog
   service name (compute, network, volume, object-store, orchestration)
4. Resource type name should be taken from the noun used in the equivalent
   command-line client command (where possible)
5. Due to 3. and 4. a hyphen is used to separate words
   (object-store, router-gateway)
6. Resources internal to heat are in the os::orchestration namespace
   and get a name which complies with the above conventions

Change-Id: Ib5f70eb00dddfb1cdcc5c8ac9fb68da86cc5eee7
"}]
commit_message:
Rename all OS:: resource types with registry mapping

This change is to demonstrate a possible new naming scheme
for native OpenStack resource types. It implements a strawman
naming scheme and provides global environment registry mappings
so that any template using an old name should continue to work
indefinitely.

The justification for this scheme is as follows:
1. All lower case, as this is easier to type and easier to read
   for non-native english readers
2. Top level namespace is 'os' for OpenStack
3. Second level namespace should be taken from the keystone catalog
   service name (compute, network, volume, object-store, orchestration)
4. Resource type name should be taken from the noun used in the equivalent
   command-line client command (where possible)
5. Due to 3. and 4. a hyphen is used to separate words
   (object-store, router-gateway)
6. Resources internal to heat are in the os::orchestration namespace
   and get a name which complies with the above conventions

Change-Id: Ib5f70eb00dddfb1cdcc5c8ac9fb68da86cc5eee7

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-30 04:46:16.000000000', 'message': "Makes client always use provided endpoint_url

When nova uses neutron-client and the client needs to authenticate with
identity it will additionally retrieve the service-catalog. The client will
then ignore the provided endpoint_url parameter given to it during
instantiation because the service-catalog retrieval process overrides that
parameter.

Using the endpoint declared in the service-catalog even though the endpoint is
given is unexpected given the precedent set by glance-client to respect that
parameter. Ensuring the parameter is used will allow users to override the
identity's catalog. This is useful if identity is in error, or if the user is
using a special development configuration.

Unit tests are included to test that said functionality occurs.

Fixes: bug #1212812
Change-Id: I743b27f92adbf251b2fe4aeba92befd9be5d460a
"}]
commit_message:
Makes client always use provided endpoint_url

When nova uses neutron-client and the client needs to authenticate with
identity it will additionally retrieve the service-catalog. The client will
then ignore the provided endpoint_url parameter given to it during
instantiation because the service-catalog retrieval process overrides that
parameter.

Using the endpoint declared in the service-catalog even though the endpoint is
given is unexpected given the precedent set by glance-client to respect that
parameter. Ensuring the parameter is used will allow users to override the
identity's catalog. This is useful if identity is in error, or if the user is
using a special development configuration.

Unit tests are included to test that said functionality occurs.

Fixes: bug #1212812
Change-Id: I743b27f92adbf251b2fe4aeba92befd9be5d460a

commit_message:
Add common code from Oslo for work with database

Moved common code for work with database from Oslo.
It contains work around session, SQLAchemy engines, wrappers, etc.

blueprint use-common-oslo-db-code

Change-Id: Icac2ac963b3f3b8364f19c64c1189c3aadef9bf4

[{'created': '2013-08-29 12:13:34.000000000', 'message': 'Load tables of service plugins when migration auto generation

When we run "neutron-db-manage revision --autogenerate", it detects
table deletion of service plugins even when they are configured.
We need to load tables of service plugins to teach alembic such
tables exist.

Change-Id: I9186d36496069c8253683bd200326b80a6565fa6
Closes-Bug: #1218338

commit_message:
Load tables of service plugins when migration auto generation

When we run "neutron-db-manage revision --autogenerate", it detects
table deletion of service plugins even when they are configured.
We need to load tables of service plugins to teach alembic such
tables exist.

Change-Id: I9186d36496069c8253683bd200326b80a6565fa6
Closes-Bug: #1218338

and remove the u'' prefixes, as it is not supported in Python3.

commit_message:
python3: Use from future import unicode_literals

use  "from future import unicode_literals" instead of u""

To the road to Python3, a possible next step would be to use the from __future__ import unicode_literals
and remove the u'' prefixes, as it is not supported in Python3.

Change-Id: Ic7afb3cf2d8dfad47b8a1626ab264f6d4f50d00e
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

subject: Bump hacking to 0.7

commit_message:
Bump hacking to 0.7

Fixed H102 errors

Hacking 0.6 already pins down pep8, pyflakes and flake8 so they can be
removed from test-requirements as they are indirect dependencies.

Co-author: Joe Gordon <joe.gordon0@gmail.com>

Change-Id: If7e79c70fe44d7e42a14cd6c710fd9986f995446

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-23 15:25:53.000000000', 'message': 'Sync py3kcompat from oslo-incubator

Python3 reorganized the standard library and moved several
functions to different modules and combined modules. Six
provides a consistent interface to the module through
six.moves

However urllib/urlparse is not covered by six.moves so
py3kcompat adds python2/python3 compatibility layer for
urllib/urlparse.

Change-Id: I98d45a84e8c2dcd965a9e5cc08d7bb341eb08bfc
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Sync py3kcompat from oslo-incubator

Python3 reorganized the standard library and moved several
functions to different modules and combined modules. Six
provides a consistent interface to the module through
six.moves

However urllib/urlparse is not covered by six.moves so
py3kcompat adds python2/python3 compatibility layer for
urllib/urlparse.

Change-Id: I98d45a84e8c2dcd965a9e5cc08d7bb341eb08bfc
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

trying to fix regression failures'}, {'account_id': 7198, 'date': '2013-08-19 19:33:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 4355, 'date': '2013-08-21 11:01:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Please add your patch on top of this one and add a unit test: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/42802"}, {'account_id': 8375, 'date': '2013-08-23 14:19:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Question.  Is this a bug or a feature?

The regression test for test_force_delete_volume is set up so that a volume with error_deleting cannot be directly deleted, but it can be forced deleted.  Is this behavior intentional?  If it is, then I can cancel this patch.'}, {'account_id': 8375, 'date': '2013-08-30 02:23:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Change abandoned.  It appears that the security model for openstack requires that if there is an error on deletion that the admin user be required to force remove the block.'}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2013-08-30 02:31:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Joseph: Any reference for that? ^    (Just curious as I have pondered similiar issues w/ deleting snapshots.)'}, {'account_id': 8375, 'date': '2013-08-30 03:05:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The only reference is the regression test that requires a force remove to get rid of error_deleting.  Once I found out that this was there, it was no longer a blocker for me.

I would like some "official" confirmation if this is intentional or not.  If it is intentional it would be nice to add code that would output a useful error message saying that you can force delete this block.'}]

[{'created': '2013-08-19 03:27:16.000000000', 'message': 'let cinder to remove block in error_deleting state

This commit allows cinder to remove a block which is an error_deleting
state.  Without this check, cinder can end up in a bad state in which
there is a block with an error, but no new block can be created since
the old one cannot be deleted.

Change-Id: I790399c5591dab2b3881c95fd19ad087c56502c0
'}]
commit_message:
let cinder to remove block in error_deleting state

This commit allows cinder to remove a block which is an error_deleting
state.  Without this check, cinder can end up in a bad state in which
there is a block with an error, but no new block can be created since
the old one cannot be deleted.

Change-Id: I790399c5591dab2b3881c95fd19ad087c56502c0

commit_message:
python3: Transition to mox3 instead of mox

In order to make the transition to mox free world,
mox needs to replaced with mox3 which is python3 compatible.

Change-Id: Id18928c7ac93b510a4867acb03896899fe1c13b0
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Bump python-cinderclient requirement to >=1.0.5

The requirement for python-cinderclient should be bumped to 1.0.5
in order to support some of the arguments (e.g. snapshots).

Change-Id: I4028c3159057ec25d6bb9df03a3c5380850c49fb

commit_message:
Use OSLO jsonutils instead of json module

For most things there is very little difference, but as we have a
jsonutils module we should probably be using it.

Change-Id: I406ea81bb56ad90cc9ff9b8b58b0d35b694dc802

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-12 20:26:37.000000000', 'message': "Fix role lookup for Active Directory

When using Keystone against an Active Directory server, assigned
roles weren't found for users.

When roles are added as DNs in the roleOccupant attribute, an LDAP
server can normalize the value so that when the entry is read later
the roleOccupant isn't exactly the same as it was when added.
Keystone needs to compare DNs properly by normalizing them.

Keystone's fake LDAP is changed to muck with roleOccupant DNs by
uppercasing attribute names (like Active Directory). The code is
fixed to correctly get the roles for users even with the modified
DNs.

Change-Id: Iaa41c3ef9febcabef0662f38b13d319a5b5583bc
Resolves-Bug: #1210675
"}, {'created': '2013-08-12 20:39:34.000000000', 'message': "Fix role lookup for Active Directory

When using Keystone against an Active Directory server, assigned
roles weren't found for users.

When roles are added as DNs in the roleOccupant attribute, an LDAP
server can normalize the value so that when the entry is read later
the roleOccupant isn't exactly the same as it was when added.
Keystone needs to compare DNs properly by normalizing them.

Keystone's fake LDAP is changed to muck with roleOccupant and
member DNs by uppercasing attribute names (like Active Directory).
The code is fixed to correctly get the roles for users with the
modified DNs.

commit_message:
Fix role lookup for Active Directory

When using Keystone against an Active Directory server, assigned
roles weren't found for users.

When roles are added as DNs in the roleOccupant attribute, an LDAP
server can normalize the value so that when the entry is read later
the roleOccupant isn't exactly the same as it was when added.
Keystone should compare users by ID rather than by DN.
(Note that this is how the comparison is done in Grizzly.)

Keystone's fake LDAP is changed to muck with roleOccupant and
member DNs by uppercasing attribute names (like Active Directory).
The code is fixed to compare users by ID rather than DN.

Change-Id: Iaa41c3ef9febcabef0662f38b13d319a5b5583bc
Resolves-Bug: #1210675

femto nit about the commit message: the blueprint name is nvp-distributed-router ;)

The other note is: in the blueprint page you say 'A CLI option for specifying the router type by name instead of id should be considered'. So if we do consider passing the router type via CLI/API don't we need to validate that the Quantum backend can actually honor the request, a bit like I did for the extra route bp? See nvplib code for details."}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-07-08 20:57:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

To try and answer your question, which I probably failed to understand, we can add validation for service provider rejecting requests with invalid provider ids. This is tantamount to 'unmasking' an exception I am currently masking; backward compatibility can be ensured if missing provider_id is interpreted as 'default provider id'.

However, I am failing to understand what the relationship with nvplib would be.
I am guessing that you want to validate whether the backend (NVP then) actually supports the service provider specified in the request. I guess this could be done, and if you solved it in another patch, I will gladly piggy back on to your work. As I see this as something of relatively minor importance (as if one does not support the distribute routers in the backend should not expose its service provider in the first place), I hope you wouldn't mind If I just do this bit work on top of your static route patch once both are merged.

 I don't think there's any distinction when setting service provider through CLI or API. Or is it?"}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2013-07-08 21:26:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

No, there's no distinction between API and CLI.

To rephrase my question, what happens if a client wants a distributed router but the NSX backend does not support it?"}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-07-08 21:29:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Short answer: who deploys neutron should ensure only appropriate service providers are configured. Hence, if backend does not support distribute router, don't configure its service provider.

However it is possible to validate whether the backend (NVP then) actually supports the service provider specified in the request. Since you solved it in another patch, I will gladly piggy back on to your work. I see this as something of relatively minor importance; indeed if one does not support the distribute drouters in the backend should its service provider should not be exposed in the first place.

I hope it is ok for you if I just do this bit work on top of your static routes patch once both are merged."}, {'account_id': 5983, 'date': '2013-07-09 02:37:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (6 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 6072, 'date': '2013-07-09 12:17:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The question I have is the next:
Currently RouterServiceProviderBinding directly refers service provider object in the db.

What will happen if corresponding provider entry disappears from conf or from db (if/when we move to dynamically configurable providers)?

I was planning to solve this for lbaas via ProviderResourceAssociation: in case conf/db changes, we loose association, but preserve logical object, which can be associated with existing providers.
Does this applies to your case?'}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2013-07-09 21:02:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Blueprint nicira-distributed-router

This patch adds support for NSX distributed routers leveraging
the 'routerservicetype' extension.
In order to ensure backward compatibility, routers without
a service provider specification are treated as 'standard',
centralized routers.

Change-Id: Iaab9ffb6071c93990be711ebb56c212230544a7a

commit_message:
Support for NVP distributed router

Blueprint nvp-distributed-router

This patch adds support for NVP distributed logical routers
adding a simple attribute extension.
The default router type can be controlled used the default_router_type
option in the nvp section of neutron configuration.
In order to ensure backward compatibility, pre-existing routers
will be treated as centralized routers.

Change-Id: Iaab9ffb6071c93990be711ebb56c212230544a7a

commit_message:
Enable SQL tests for oauth

Enables testing of the SQL backend for oauth.
As a result of running the tests, I noticed that this also
fixes an update_consumer test cases too.

fixes bug: #1215483
fixes bug: #1216447

Change-Id: I206d164caa66c3211cfc216d13e3d0bab0e7d54a

commit_message:
moves addCleanup few lines upper to avoid potential leftovers

this is a quick fix which corrects an oversight, the addCleanup
supposed to be used after the create step was instead placed right
after the get step

Change-Id: Ide099e1e1b0dcffb42e7c3f86f787d10fbcb34fd

'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2013-08-29 07:17:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(3 inline comments)

This change is good, it should merge.

I think I'm jaded by dealing with file system layout for so long, I can't really form an opinion about the comments... they're all true to the best of my knowledge?

OTOH, the asserts sorta rub me because when I see asserts I'm normally thinking "ok, we need to be careful here; we're unsure and making some assumptions; and we'd prefer to have the whole thing blow up rather than make a wrong assumption and break something" - but *those* asserts just validating python's control structures?  Yeah ts_file and data_file will be None every iteration of the loop until you set them and break out of the loop - at least that what the code says.  So the asserts end up just being more comments, but sort of more cryptic than the comments which already say that because they *could* actually effect the behavior; will they, I'm scared?!

And in fact they do, when I break the code those asserts start to fire off and Error all the diskfile tests - but sort of in boring generic AssertionError ways; if I *remove* the asserts *and* break the code I get much more meaningful test *Failures* which describe how the observed behavior does not match the expected result.'}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-08-29 18:23:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> OTOH, the asserts sorta rub me because when I see asserts I'm
> normally thinking "ok, we need to be careful here; we're unsure and
> making some assumptions; and we'd prefer to have the whole thing
> blow up rather than make a wrong assumption and break something" -

So the asserts where added with this thinking:

"The entrance to this block of code makes the following assumptions:"

Over the years, I have debugged enough problems that resulted from
code assuming one state when it is can be invoked from other states as
well.

> but *those* asserts just validating python's control structures?
> Yeah ts_file and data_file will be None every iteration of the loop
> until you set them and break out of the loop - at least that what
> the code says.

This loop is subtle enough that it took my clouded mind a bit longer
to understand it than I had expected. I felt placing the comments and
assertions there helped me out, and that they might be a benefit to
others.

> So the asserts end up just being more comments, but sort of more
> cryptic than the comments which already say that because they
> *could* actually effect the behavior; will they, I'm scared?!

When the code is installed using python -O, I believe assertions do
not fire, which is the intention.

> And in fact they do, when I break the code those asserts start to
> fire off and Error all the diskfile tests - but sort of in boring
> generic AssertionError ways; if I *remove* the asserts *and* break
> the code I get much more meaningful test *Failures* which describe
> how the observed behavior does not match the expected result.

When I change the "break" statements to "continue", all the tests
pass with flying colors, which says we don't have good unit tests
for this code. That alone says to me that these assertions are useful.

When I further change the .meta continue statement to a break, the
assertions do fire in a few cases.

I'll add unit tests to catch this explicitly.

I added the comments to help remove the subtly. I added the assertions
to concretely describe in the code what is expected. Comments tend to
suffer from bit rot more quickly than assertions, so if I could keep
one or the other, I would like to keep the assertions and not the
comments.

Changing the assertions to emit a condensed version of the comment is
another possible option.

Just the same, I don't care if we remove them entirely.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2013-08-29 19:03:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Comments or assert's can stay or go - It's fine by me either way.  I do sorta find them distracting, but only when I'm trying to read that block of code - and how often is that!?

I did validate some unittest failures when you change continue to break on *this* branch (even with the asserts pulled out).  Changing the loop in Diskfile.__init__  on *master* however did NOT seem to cause the same failures.  I believe that's because the "remove unlinkold" change is doing a better job of making sure there's only ever one file in there anyway.  You should rebase this.

So, yes - some explicit unittests for the behavior of the loop when faced with multiple files would be greatly preferable and much more useful IMHO than any amount of comments and benign assertions in the body of the loop.  But that's just *me* having "debugged enough problems that resulted from code assuming one state when it is can be invoked from other states", YMMV - I did +2 it anyway ;)

I had some other comments inline; not sure if you saw them?'}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-08-29 19:46:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2013-08-29 19:57:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

These tests are so good we should merge it even without the other changes - which are also good. commit_message:
Refactor DiskFile init logic into multiple methods

The DiskFile constructor needs to grow a bit in the future it is was
already considered "large" by some. This breaks the logic up into
three main parts:

  1. Determine if the object exists, fetching the on-disk file(s) to
     use
  2. Finish the object construction when we have a tombstone file
  3. Finish the object construction when we have a regular data file,
     and optionally a fast-POST metadata file

We added a number of assertions as a way of documenting the expected
behavior of the loop that figures out the on-disk file to use, and a
set of unit tests to verify the loop works as expected.

Change-Id: I1503b7561e280ded3222a09514edc59ac26dbc65
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>

commit_message:
add require grant allow

Some httpd servers are set up so that the root directory defaults
to denying privileges causing horizon to fail.  This change adds
a command to allow overrides in the horizon directory,

Change-Id: Ieec7bf9a1caa2ae71c0327ca85f5976ad41af371

commit_message:
Adds Hyper-V compute inspector

Blueprint: hyper-v-agent

Adds a compute inspector for Hyper-V. Supports Windows Server / Hyper-V
Server 2012 and above.

Disk stats are supported starting with Hyper-V 2012 R2.

Change-Id: Ib6499b631a2f7e406198b13f4b5788a3b880fb1b

commit_message:
powervm: Use FixedIntervalLoopingCall for polling LPAR status

This patch moves the code in stop_lpar that polls the LPAR status for
'Not Activated' to it's own helper method that uses
FixedIntervalLoopingCall with an eventlet timeout.

Also moves the hard-coded timeout to the constants file.

Builds on top of change Iad64dda79f46d18c7aa5bee12ed41e7a01853d34 to
verify the new looping call and timeout code works with the
test_stop_lpar_timeout test case in that patch.

Change-Id: I59586d3cb242d40ee5e09e48274de11cb5638717

If you make a call for a method on the manager, it is not defined on the manager, and it is defined on the driver, it will be passed through to the driver's method.  As it stands, these new methods are superfluous as implemented.

You're not actually moving anything, commit message doesn't make sense."}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2013-08-23 02:02:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

notifications to be sent from the assignment Manager CRUD instead of
implementing it in the drivers or the keystone/identity/core.py Manager.
This is required by blueprint notifications.

Change-Id: I81b4eca720615b38a38858aecd734af8ab383d91

commit_message:
Add project CRUD to assignment_api Manager

Specifically, the "proxy" methods on identity_api for following methods
are removed in favor of assignment_api:

- create_project
- update_project
- delete_project

The majority of this change is a refactor in support of the incomplete
work done for bp split-identity in
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/33745/

Notification decorators are also added to these 3 methods in support of
bp notifications and bug 967832.

Change-Id: I81b4eca720615b38a38858aecd734af8ab383d91

[{'created': '2013-08-29 08:22:47.000000000', 'message': 'Add kwargs to create_volume in tests/utils.py

Add availability_zone parameter and kwargs to make create_volume
function more flexible in order to use this function in
unit tests.
The goal is to remove inner _create_volume function in:
- db/test_transfers.py
- api/contrib/test_backups.py
- test_gpfs.py
- test_volume_transfer.py
- test_volume.py
and to use create_volume from tests/utils instead.

Change-Id: I2d9456ff3ff1cd945042f19c47e40f9f0ec0fe8a
'}]
commit_message:
Add kwargs to create_volume in tests/utils.py

Add availability_zone parameter and kwargs to make create_volume
function more flexible in order to use this function in
unit tests.
The goal is to remove inner _create_volume function in:
- db/test_transfers.py
- api/contrib/test_backups.py
- test_gpfs.py
- test_volume_transfer.py
- test_volume.py
and to use create_volume from tests/utils instead.

Change-Id: I2d9456ff3ff1cd945042f19c47e40f9f0ec0fe8a

commit_message:
Add NFS/GlusterFS support to brick library

Refactor NFS driver to use the brick library to perform mounts
rather than duplicating the mount code. Some of the NFS unit
test code was rewritten to test the brick implementation because
the old mount code was moved.

The Gluster driver was slightly affected in the refactoring, but
does not yet use brick to perform attaches.

bug 1214748

Change-Id: Ib29f83fabe407f9591191e9fd19e6306ca9960cf

Remove methods:

	timefunc()
	logging_error()

commit_message:
Remove unused methods from cinder.utils

These methods and class  were left over from the split from Nova and are unused still.

Remove methods:
	debug()
	utf8()
	map_dict_keys()
	check_isinstance()
	timefunc()
	logging_error()
	temporary_mutation()
	generate_mac_address()

Remove class:
	UndoManager

Change-Id: Id3a94ff9066627b5c0efef068f8c569423f1e9d8

commit_message:
Multi storage backend support for Nexenta driver

Recover nexenta prefix for host, user, password and iscsi_port
config options.

Change-Id: I8bdc54f391145193b7813e0e411afa39d07d9aad

cache region from modificaiton during tests using liberal application of

'}, {'created': '2013-08-29 22:09:25.000000000', 'message': 'Add Memory Isolating Cache Proxy

cache region from modificaiton during tests using liberal application of

commit_message:
Add Memory Isolating Cache Proxy

Created a specialized dogpile.cache proxy to isolate in-memory data in the
cache region from modificaiton during tests using liberal application of
copy.deepcopy for get/set operations.

partial-blueprint: caching-layer-for-driver-calls
Change-Id: Id6d27219b75ea7e6709d220542dd31c4a6c7aa04

commit_message:
Fix unsuitable assertTrue/assertFalse in api ut

Some usages of assertTrue()/assertFalse() are incorrect, improve
them to more explicit assert from the unit test suite.

Closes-Bug: #1218621
Change-Id: I22be2af05f06e91020dbaa4cf08bf395d68f563b

commit_message:
Add delay in swift-bench

With enable write affinity, it's necessary to wait until
replication has moved things to their proper homes before
running delete request. With write affinity turned on, only
nodes in local region will get the object right after PUT request.

Fix bug #1198926

Change-Id: I3aa8933d45c47a010ae05561e12176479e7c9bcc

for a PCI devices in a dictionary, resource tracker will transform the
information according to database requirement.

commit_message:
PCI device auto discover

Hypervisor discovers and returns information about assignable PCI devices
as xml resource. PCI auto discover provoid method to convert these to a
dict. PCI tracker will transform the information into pci device object
store it into the DataBase.

bp:pci-passthrough-base

Change-Id: I6241053668a430f573d23dc862d812259c004dfd
Signed-off-by: Yongli He <yongli.he@intel.com>
Signed-off-by: Yunhong Jiang <yunhong.jiang@intel.com>

subject: Add PCI device filters support

'}, {'created': '2013-08-09 08:54:20.000000000', 'message': "Add PCI device filters support

Cloud administrator may decide the devices that can be assigned to VM
based on vendor_id or device_id etc.

this is whitelist based filter.by default None device can be assigned
except explicit define a filter for the device.

configuration option 'pci_passthrough_whitelist' can be defined multi
times, each for one type device.

bp:pci-passthrough-base

Change-Id: I03f2a0c098198a32abedff0773e9f94e3d7d2f28
Signed-off-by: Yunhong Jiang <yunhong.jiang@intel.com>
Signed-off-by: Yongli He <yongli.he@intel.com>

"}, {'created': '2013-08-17 00:59:06.000000000', 'message': "Add PCI device filters support

Cloud administrator may decide the devices that can be assigned to VM
based on vendor_id or device_id etc.

This is whitelist based filter. No device will be assigned
except explicitly defined.

The configuration option 'pci_passthrough_whitelist' can be defined multi
times, each for one type of device.

bp:pci-passthrough-base

Change-Id: I03f2a0c098198a32abedff0773e9f94e3d7d2f28

commit_message:
Add PCI device filters support

Cloud administrator may decide the devices that can be assigned to VM
based on vendor_id or device_id etc.

This is whitelist based filter. No device will be assigned
except explicitly defined.

The configuration option 'pci_passthrough_whitelist' can be defined multi
times, each for one type of device.

bp:pci-passthrough-base

Change-Id: I03f2a0c098198a32abedff0773e9f94e3d7d2f28
Signed-off-by: Yunhong Jiang <yunhong.jiang@intel.com>
Signed-off-by: Yongli He <yongli.he@intel.com>

commit_message:
Added support for running the tests under PyPy with tox

This is a precursor to having them run under check and gate.

Change-Id: Ia512b68b5b47a88d5f7c1015cdf7151c322d293d

commit_message:
Remove redundant unit suffix

Transfer speed already has a "MB/s" unit. The "s" suffix was probably a
copy/paste mistake.

Change-Id: Iccd7894d5ca11aac8a9f98365834c5d3deef0720

commit_message:
Fix and enable gating on H302: only import modules

Fixes non-module imports and enables gating on H302 in flake8

Change-Id: I366b0ca622d5185732c6c755f8724efb8bbc80f7

[{'account_id': 970, 'date': '2013-08-13 03:01:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

There should be no new copyright statements with 'OpenStack, LLC.' they should all read 'OpenStack Foundation' as all of the LLC assets were transferred to the foundation.  Changing the exiting LLC -> Foundation is acceptable but not required.

I think H102 is just for the Apache 2.0 license header and not copyright statements.  The copyright lines are actually not checked."}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2013-08-13 03:06:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I tend to think being copyright OpenStack LLC is fine but no strong opinions.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2013-08-16 10:05:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

> I tend to think being copyright OpenStack LLC is fine but no strong opinions.

Well OpenStack LLC is definitely wrong as it no longer exists, and OpenStack Foundation is probably wrong in the majority of cases - IMO/AIUI it's definitely wrong to start attributing previously unattributed code to the Foundation, hence my comment.

See:
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/LegalIssuesFAQ#Copyright_Headers

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/legal-discuss/2013-April/000010.html

Specifically: "It's likely the only valid reason for OpenStack Foundation copyright notices on new code these days is where the code was authored by an employee or contractor of the foundation."

So at best it's meaningless, and at worst it's wrong and misleading, so my preference is to leave out the copyright notice, and definitely not to add them to existing code.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2013-08-17 00:27:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

@Steven Hardy	- Makes sense to me.  I'll keep that in mind when reviewing code going forward."}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2013-08-19 03:13:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-19 04:06:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

commit_message:
Fix License Headers and Enable Gating on H102

Add ASLv2 headers to files that were missing it.

fixes bug #1211587

Change-Id: Iede918e1ce84993cee4ecbb2d9c2606627fa412e

commit_message:
Forbid update of subnet gateway ip when in use by a port

Bug 1186322

If a port is currently using the subnet's gateway IP, which usually
happens for router interfaces, do not allow updates to the gateway IP.
This patch adds an extra query on the IPAllocation model, which
returns at most a single record, and is executed in _validate_subnet
only when the subnet is updated.

Change-Id: Ie29be1b83f9a639562bfc84f3f2c082833126d32

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-06 17:26:00.000000000', 'message': 'Improve dhcp agent structure to support multiple dhcp models

This patch introduces some minor refactoring of the dhcp
code so that it is easy to support both an in-node/same
process dhcp provisioning model (e.g. with dnsmasq) and
proxy model, where DHCP is provided by an external node.

Higher separation of concerns is also achieved by doing
better data encapsulation.

Implements blueprint dhcp-flexi-model

commit_message:
Improve dhcp agent structure to support multiple dhcp models

This patch introduces some minor refactoring of the dhcp
code so that it is easy to support both an in-node/same
process dhcp provisioning model (e.g. with dnsmasq) and
proxy model, where DHCP is provided by an external node.

Higher separation of concerns is also achieved by doing
better data encapsulation.

Implements blueprint dhcp-flexi-model

Change-Id: Icbd215e9682ecaebb6a4300423f3564e8e677566

commit_message:
feat: marconi-proxy forwarding

This patchset inttroduces forwarding. The following resources are now
passed on to marconi:
- claim-related requests
- message-related requests

Furthermore, on queue metadata operations, the queue catalogue is now
updated with the desired metadata.

Change-Id: Iaf062b3587173dcfead823b3b0223eccfffd48d1
Implements: blueprint placement-service

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-23 20:06:07.000000000', 'message': "Revert task state when terminate_instance fails

Calls to terminate_instance leave the instance task state as-is when
they raise an exception - this was introduced in Ie5701e5c as a
work-around for a bug with quota accounting, but introduced bugs with
power-state syncing. Ib72de1a4 removed the need for the original
work-around, and this change reverts Ie5701e5c.

Ie5701e5c worked around a bug in quota accounting by using the instance's
task state as a signal to communicate between the nova.compute.manager
and nova.compute.api modules: if the manager's terminate_instance method
failed, it would leave the instance task state as DELETING. If the user
retried the delete, the api would check the task state: if the
instance's task state was already DELETING, it would not decrement the
user's quota a second time.

Unfortunately, leaving an instance with an active task had the
side-effect of preventing the VM power-state from synchronizing, wedging
the instance (bug 1177584 and bug 1212420).

Ib72de1a4 changed the quota accounting mechanism, moving the quota
handling code out of the api module. The api code for the work-around to
check the DELETING task state was removed. However, the code for the
work-around in the manager was never cleaned up.

This change cleans up the nova.compute.manager work-around code, making
terminate_instance revert the task state to None upon failure.
Power-state syncing should work again, and quota handling is unaffected
by the change.

Fixes: bug 1177584, bug 1212420
Change-Id: I42c68d16dca56703d6b192bb452883e4d5ca80df
"}]
commit_message:
Revert task state when terminate_instance fails

Calls to terminate_instance leave the instance task state as-is when
they raise an exception - this was introduced in Ie5701e5c as a
work-around for a bug with quota accounting, but introduced bugs with
power-state syncing. Ib72de1a4 removed the need for the original
work-around, and this change reverts Ie5701e5c.

Ie5701e5c worked around a bug in quota accounting by using the instance's
task state as a signal to communicate between the nova.compute.manager
and nova.compute.api modules: if the manager's terminate_instance method
failed, it would leave the instance task state as DELETING. If the user
retried the delete, the api would check the task state: if the
instance's task state was already DELETING, it would not decrement the
user's quota a second time.

Unfortunately, leaving an instance with an active task had the
side-effect of preventing the VM power-state from synchronizing, wedging
the instance (bug 1177584 and bug 1212420).

Ib72de1a4 changed the quota accounting mechanism, moving the quota
handling code out of the api module. The api code for the work-around to
check the DELETING task state was removed. However, the code for the
work-around in the manager was never cleaned up.

This change cleans up the nova.compute.manager work-around code, making
terminate_instance revert the task state to None upon failure.
Power-state syncing should work again, and quota handling is unaffected
by the change.

Fixes: bug 1177584, bug 1212420
Change-Id: I42c68d16dca56703d6b192bb452883e4d5ca80df

commit_message:
cli: add messages to assertTrue

1) Unify assertion of 'usage: service-name' from
   {cinder, glance, keystone, neutron} help tests
   into assertFirstLineStartsWith method, which provides
   more usefull failure message.
2) Add failure message to assertTrue in keystone-catalog
   test.

(cherry picked from commit 4c18fa1bbf85e3e8d0352b45a6f235afaeea4081)

Conflicts:
	cli/__init__.py
	tempest/cli/simple_read_only/test_cinder.py
	tempest/cli/simple_read_only/test_glance.py
	tempest/cli/simple_read_only/test_neutron.py

Change-Id: I3abba1d9509bee649aa1675beee4153341b1e170

commit_message:
Remove capabilities.enabled from test_host_filters

Update the unit tests to reflect the fact that capabilities will not be
returning enabled any more.  Leave capabilities.enabled in the json
filter tests, as even though capabilities.enabled isn't there the test
still checks the json filters functionality.

Part of bp no-compute-fanout-to-scheduler

Change-Id: Ia8d1dd1ac1ecf609586528f82d4c11650bb328c5

commit_message:
Fail puppet-lint on warnings

Puppet-lint will now fail if there is any warnings.

Disable 'names_containing_dash' check until the remaining classes
are completely removed or we find a way to add exceptions.

Change-Id: I09c15fcfbac82904a3d90328683d8c39b1bcaf0d

commit_message:
Deprecate classes with hyphens

Puppet does not recommend the use of hyphens in class names.

This change deprecates classes with hypens and inform the users
to use the new ones. Backward compatibility is preserved.

Change-Id: Ib4ce5ec3f9354d77397d97500811ccac2a0ff395

commit_message:
Fix incorrect usage of assertTrue()

The usage of assertTrue() is incorrect, more explicit assert
from the unit test suite(like assertIsNotNone or assertIn)
should be used instead.

Fixes: bug #1217028
Change-Id: I30a80bc9e122d28c22b698e0cb97068c1040bfc3
Signed-off-by: Rosario Di Somma <rosario.disomma@dreamhost.com>

commit_message:
Add context information to download plugins

This patch sends the context information into the download plugins
via  kwargs.  This will allow download modules like swift to use
the keystone auth information.

Change-Id: I105cc7d7dd76e4eadfeefdc7ca65f9eab38098b7
blueprint: image-multiple-location

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-29 07:11:46.000000000', 'message': 'Fix logging problem for stress test wrappers

If using a stress test wrapper like UnitTest the logging output
only points to UnitTest itself and not to the executed action. This
makes log messages not readable.

Change-Id: I33afbf89f5a2cd922a569da62e7dbd7eeee61e8b
Fixes: bug #1216274
'}, {'created': '2013-08-29 10:58:02.000000000', 'message': 'Fix logging problem for stress test wrappers

If using a stress test wrapper like UnitTest the logging output
only points to UnitTest itself and not to the executed action. This
makes log messages not readable.

Change-Id: I33afbf89f5a2cd922a569da62e7dbd7eeee61e8b
Fixes: bug #1216274
'}]
commit_message:
Fix logging problem for stress test wrappers

If using a stress test wrapper like UnitTest the logging output
only points to UnitTest itself and not to the executed action. This
makes log messages not readable.

Change-Id: I33afbf89f5a2cd922a569da62e7dbd7eeee61e8b
Fixes: bug #1216274

commit_message:
Add volume snapshot delete API test case

Later in this patch series I'm adding some additional functionality to
the snapshot delete API.  I noticed that there was no unit tests for the
API.  Go ahead and add a base test case now that I can add more to
later.

Related to blueprint qemu-assisted-snapshots

Change-Id: Iff4e4c0e7de48d5375d66271dfc8ad4cbdff2a31

commit_message:
Assisted snapshots compute API plumbing

This patch adds the plumbing necessary to get assisted volume snapshot
calls down from compute.api down to a compute host.

Part of blueprint qemu-assisted-snapshots

Change-Id: I18d89b16c3e4bbbb2cdf3fe70c958f7e671e78ec

commit_message:
chore: Update openstack.common, add lockutils

This patch updates openstack.common to HEAD and also adds
lockutils to openstack-common.conf in anticipation of
pulling in the cache module when it lands.

Change-Id: I714e03c4eba9e98b92144f2b2f227799d104f1bd

The document root can be obtained from the service catalog, so
that users can join two URIs to access the doc.

The health endpoint is removed from homedoc at the same time,
since it's an API for diagnose, not for end-users.

Change-Id: I589ff88730302bc553041ecccb9687f7dbcaa9ab
"}]
commit_message:
feat(wsgi): homedoc now ships relative URIs

The document root can be obtained from the service catalog, so
that users can join two URIs to access the doc.

The health endpoint is removed from homedoc at the same time,
since it's an API for diagnose, not for end-users.

Change-Id: I589ff88730302bc553041ecccb9687f7dbcaa9ab

[{'created': '2013-08-22 16:23:52.000000000', 'message': 'Fix AttachInterfacesTest error

This commit fixes some issues in AttachInterfacesTest.
* There is a problem to get the return value, TypeError is
  occurring.
* Assign the JSON or XML to _interface, but it is not specified
  in the method.
* Add a process to wait until the "ACTIVE" status.
  Because the status is "DOWN" when a interface is created.

Fixes bug 1164894

Change-Id: I71ec9e46eb15e70f870b7a833d5433fa351c42eb
(cherry picked from commit ba9e909dfb8983fc9fd51f7d79b772d03abfe3b0)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix AttachInterfacesTest error

This commit fixes some issues in AttachInterfacesTest.
* There is a problem to get the return value, TypeError is
  occurring.
* Assign the JSON or XML to _interface, but it is not specified
  in the method.
* Add a process to wait until the "ACTIVE" status.
  Because the status is "DOWN" when a interface is created.

Fixes bug 1164894

Change-Id: I71ec9e46eb15e70f870b7a833d5433fa351c42eb
(cherry picked from commit ba9e909dfb8983fc9fd51f7d79b772d03abfe3b0)

commit_message:
Add ssh check to quantum smoke test.

 * Doing a ping check to verify that a vm is reachable may result
   in a false positive if the target ip is routed in error to a
   nonetheless pingable host.  This patch adds an ssh check that will
   fail if the target is not configured with the expected (and
   dynamically generated) ssh keypair.
 * Adding the ssh check uncovered a bug in security group creation -
   source group rules were being used that restricted traffic to
   ports associated with the security group.  This is now fixed.
 * Addresses bug 1182343

Conflicts:
	tempest/scenario/manager.py
	tempest/scenario/test_network_basic_ops.py

Change-Id: I4112ad9a8854fc113d5fefc7ea03a55da7d0ed1b
(cherry picked from commit af292e8eb7c5318541eb6e88ccde7d5b7c00cb71)

'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-08-26 14:45:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

ssh_channel_timeout is 60 by default, It is a wrong name, it should 'ssh_operation_timeout'/'ssh_command_timeout'.

With the new version it might be 'ssh_poll_interval'. 

The ssh_timeout got a relatively huge timeout becuse it needs to wait until the machine boots, it can be almost minute in several cases. Now the 400 sec ssh_timeout is higher then the default 250 sec default test case timeout.

The old usage was using it as timeout for command execution, after the machine booted. Assuming the poll will not return without a response on the channel and we do not have operation which takes more than 60 sec.

The ssh_channel_timeout does not changed by devstack, so it can be safely renamed.

If we do not want command timeout, it should be renamed to 'ssh_poll_interval',  if we need it 'ssh_operation_timeout' or 'ssh_command_timeout'.

(We might also consider removing  this option, and hard coding a sane value.)

I would suggest a rename option to 'ssh_poll_interval' in order to be less confusing."}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-08-27 05:22:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-23 07:56:59.000000000', 'message': 'Fix ssh timeout issue

SSH client is using a connection timeout and an execution timeout. For
command execution, if the executed command did not generate output
within channel timeout, it was considered as a timeout. This patch will
issue subsequent polls within timeout.

fixes bug 1215794

Change-Id: I90b9cb7c9cebcb78655b6c1a46f9fb09ff7deb5e
'}, {'created': '2013-08-23 11:08:49.000000000', 'message': "Fix ssh timeout issue

SSH client is using a socket timeout and an execution timeout. For
command execution, if the executed command did not generate output
within the channel timeout, test dies with TimeoutException. This is
misleading, because it wasn't the command that timed out, it just did
not generate output within channel timeout.

fixes bug 1215794

Change-Id: I90b9cb7c9cebcb78655b6c1a46f9fb09ff7deb5e
"}, {'created': '2013-08-23 12:53:36.000000000', 'message': "Fix ssh timeout issue

SSH client is using a socket timeout and an execution timeout. For
command execution, if the executed command did not generate output
within the channel timeout, test dies with TimeoutException. This is
misleading, because it wasn't the command that timed out, it just did
not generate output within channel timeout.

fixes bug 1215794

Change-Id: I90b9cb7c9cebcb78655b6c1a46f9fb09ff7deb5e
"}]
commit_message:
Fix ssh timeout issue

SSH client is using a socket timeout and an execution timeout. For
command execution, if the executed command did not generate output
within the channel timeout, test dies with TimeoutException. This is
misleading, because it wasn't the command that timed out, it just did
not generate output within channel timeout.

fixes bug 1215794

Change-Id: I90b9cb7c9cebcb78655b6c1a46f9fb09ff7deb5e

commit_message:
Add common "create_server_snapshot" method

There are some "create server-snapshot" methods in scenario tests,
and they will increase in the future by increasing scenario tests.
This patch adds common "create_server_snapshot" method to parent
class and uses it instead of each implementation.

Change-Id: Ib8a222d74828933c48bc6b0e8350cc072f01af4d

commit_message:
Notify on task reversion

When a runner and its associated task are
reverted we should fire off notifications
that this is occuring so that others can
perform various activities when this occurs.

Change-Id: I3fc797255e5cacd0d5cff9cb6ec444ccb9e7ac2e

add an example of a auth body that shows oauth1 as an authentication
method.

commit_message:
Don't descent into target dirs

build_affected_books failed on my system due to an invalid target/..xml
file.

Don't descend into "target" subdirectories for determining which books
are affected.

Change-Id: Iaadaacd26f3e3542c6de55bff52f871404ba9c11

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-28 17:40:34.000000000', 'message': 'Remove unused file openstack-compute-admin/section_keystone_middleware.xml

This file was introduced as part of change
I6c35b2a50be25a3aa06e3f951dec8598315503ec. Looking at the history of the
change, the file was first split out from ch_identity_mgmt.xml but later
the contents moved back in - and the extra file was kept. So, this was committed by
accident and the file is unused.

Change-Id: I67da2bb17c5d79c4cb436f359a1c28cc105fd236
'}]
commit_message:
Remove unused file openstack-compute-admin/section_keystone_middleware.xml

This file was introduced as part of change
I6c35b2a50be25a3aa06e3f951dec8598315503ec. Looking at the history of the
change, the file was first split out from ch_identity_mgmt.xml but later
the contents moved back in - and the extra file was kept. So, this was committed by
accident and the file is unused.

Change-Id: I67da2bb17c5d79c4cb436f359a1c28cc105fd236

btw, any update about quota reservation part?"}, {'account_id': 6493, 'date': '2013-08-19 18:40:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Zhi, I have been trying to figure out a good way to handle that.  Because the size is not always given upfront the only way to handle this would be to check the quota after all of the data arrived and reject the upload at that point.  This is safer for sure, but it will waste time/resources.

Another thought would be to check it up front, and at the end.  This is redundant but it would cover the corner cases and have that optimization.

Any thoughts?'}, {'account_id': 6493, 'date': '2013-08-19 19:53:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: (3 inline comments)

Great work John! Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 4463, 'date': '2013-08-25 17:40:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

-1 is for same testclass name.Let me know if I missed somethign, and can dismiss the -1.

Also another question I had which is not directly related to the patch but might have an indirect impact is as follows. How do we handle situations where a user has issued a deleted image, then the image record is deleted first, then when u go to delete the actual image in data store, the delete fails for some reason. So there is no documentation of the left over storage space still being used in the image record."}, {'account_id': 6493, 'date': '2013-08-25 23:23:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

iccha: you are correct about the same test name, I will fix that.

Good question with the failed delete.  I think I would have to have specifics to completely address the concern but as of now I think that the quota only applies to storage that glance 'owns'.  In an earlier discussion it was decided that once a location is added to glance that the glance storage driver "owns" that location, and thus when a delete is issued that data is deleted as well.  It is up to the storage driver to properly delete data.  If there are circumstances where a driver cannot properly delete the data then the driver must have some sort of contract with the storage system about cleaning up orphaned data.  But in any case it should be outside of the scope of glance and quotas.'}, {'account_id': 6493, 'date': '2013-08-25 23:59:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 16.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-26 00:50:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Works for me
