revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-19 22:34:35.000000000', 'message': "Add a storage quota

This patch adds a storage quota that is applied against the sum total
of a users storage consumption against all configured storage systems.
A single quota is applied to all users via the configuration option
'total_storage_quota'.  Most of the patch is about enforcement so
when a separate service for quota management emerges in OpenStack the
per user value to enforce can be obtained from that service but the
enforcement code will remain the same.

blueprint: glance-basic-quotas
docImpact

Change-Id: I251832f7372c70942be6f0c6aa12285145dd7c18

commit_message:
Add a storage quota

This patch adds a storage quota that is applied against the sum total
of a users storage consumption against all configured storage systems.
A single quota is applied to all users via the configuration option
'total_storage_quota'.  Most of the patch is about enforcement so
when a separate service for quota management emerges in OpenStack the
per user value to enforce can be obtained from that service but the
enforcement code will remain the same.

blueprint glance-basic-quotas
docImpact
Change-Id: I251832f7372c70942be6f0c6aa12285145dd7c18

commit_message:
Refactor System Tests

This patch,
1. Renames 'System Tests' to 'Functional Tests'.
2. Reduces LOC by using ddt.
3. Removes test dependencies & the numbering convention used earlier.
4. Re-organizes the test suite structure.

blueprint refactor-system-tests

Change-Id: Ife236abf867b678beb72ea3a26a06d895ed8ad4b

"}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2013-08-16 18:04:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(6 inline comments)

It's difficult to really comment on a patch that is so far from actually working. But basically this feature has been long-planned and should be really simple to implement. There's no need to change the snapshot API. It's already designed so you can switch it over to handle_snapshot_delete() + check_delete_complete() for the Snapshot policy and handle_delete() + check_delete_complete() for the Delete policy by just converting stuff to tasks and adding check_delete_complete().

Patch 1 (Implement parallel delete):
* Poll self.check_delete_complete() and yield in Resource.delete()
* Make Resource.destroy() a wrappertask that yields self.delete()
* Change all the places where Resource.delete() or Resource.destroy() are called to use a TaskRunner().

[So, about 15 lines of actual changes and 500 lines of unit tests where res.destroy() -> TaskRunner(res.destroy)()]

Patch 2 (Parallelise Volume delete):
* Make Volume.delete() a wrappertask and yield self._backup() instead of starting a task for it.
* Implement Volume.check_delete_complete().

[Again, ~15 lines of changes]

Patch 3 (Parallelise Instance delete):
* Exactly what you have in instance.py

[Exactly 13 lines of changes]

Patch 4 (Parallelise StackResource delete):
* Make a TaskRunner to run the delete task of parser.Stack in StackResource.delete_nested(), start it and return it.
* Implement StackResource.check_delete_complete()

[<10 lines of changes]"}, {'account_id': 7230, 'date': '2013-08-20 18:36:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (5 inline comments)

Very minor things. The try/finally is the most puzzling."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2013-08-27 16:05:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(20 inline comments)

Looking much better. Still a couple of issues to clear up, and some concerns I have with the unit tests - particularly the parts that appear designed to cover up any possible regressions in this patch.

Also, as discussed in the review of patch set 5, there are at least 4 logical changes here that should be in separate patches (read http://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages for the OpenStack policy). Please resumbit this as a series of independent patches, don't force reviewers to figure out which parts are related to which every time."}, {'account_id': 7230, 'date': '2013-08-28 19:27:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: (14 inline comments)

Thanks Zane and Clint for your comments. I am working on implementing those comments and splitting this into multiple patches.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2013-08-29 13:54:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: (2 inline comments)

commit_message:
Use stack_task for stack delete

This change is to use stack_task for stack delete operation
so that resources deletion can happen in parallel

Blueprint parallel-delete

Change-Id: Iad05ff50fa676b33ec9ff35724b5843e7ac5e5ea

commit_message:
Have runner keep the exception

If the runner when executing caused an exception to
be thrown then it is nice to keep the exc_info()
associated with that exception for later usage in
stack-traces, rethrowing or similar...

Change-Id: I32080eae06977acdfb367756693069245a8db5d7

documentation will discourage their use.

Change-Id: Iad2f9c39f9d92465ada5ecb6001cfc2b225cc01f
Related-Bug: #986980

commit_message:
Removes KVS references from the documentation

KVS backends are deprecated and removing references to them from the
documentation will discourage their use.

Change-Id: Iad2f9c39f9d92465ada5ecb6001cfc2b225cc01f
Related-Bug: #986980

There are margin for improving the performance of the make_health_monitor_dict at scale. You're now accessing the pools relationship which will trigger a SELECT statement for each health monitor.

Either consider eager loading or something like we did for the _extend_dict methods to avoid this overhead, but this can be done in another patch.

I don't think we have a docimpact process yet, but it would be nice if you could file a bug in netconn-api to remember us that we need to update the hm specification."}, {'account_id': 6072, 'date': '2013-08-20 09:41:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Add list of pool ids to HealthMonitor dict

List of pool ids will allow users (and horizon dashboard) to
show associations between pools and monitors more conveniently.

fixes bug 1212258

Change-Id: Ie1e48e554382a6a4df9e1ba6312c505ba2ca8c02

"Replace nova client with cinder client to use volume" for bp/implement-volume-extend
replaced nova_volume_url with cinder_url. The purpose of the change was to support
Cinder's recently acquired ability to extend volumes. The original changeset missed
the CONF files, leaving the nova_volume_url artifact.

commit_message:
Update nova_volume_url to cinder_url in CONF files

"Replace nova client with cinder client to use volume" for
bp/implement-volume-extend replaced nova_volume_url with cinder_url.
The purpose of the change was to support Cinder's recently acquired
ability to extend volumes. The original changeset missed the CONF
files, leaving the nova_volume_url artifact.

Change-Id: Ic814d8cef424c4d1e18e531beb9302da9e273eb6
Closes-Bug: #1218152

commit_message:
Add Cinder API v2 to Keystone catalog

API v2 is enabled by default since Grizzly, but was never in the
catalog.

Change-Id: Ie86cf6f9ad2cf41112ff6142ba9a01fe41ea01a8

commit_message:
Add support for heat resource templates

These are resources that are defined as a template and
can be customised by a deployer.

Change-Id: Ia739a36d627b7cfec26641b89513355e65cd1d1f

commit_message:
Use distutil version classes

Instead of using our own version comparision
and extraction just use the distutils provided
one instead. This will allow us to associate
and compare task versions with a slightly less
hand-crafted algorithm.

Change-Id: Ieedab787cbc9e2217d5c4d75d59c0699ec6a0b29

Yeah, I don't get why this is using strings.

http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSCloudFormation/latest/UserGuide/aws-properties-ec2-security-group-ingress.html

says that FromPort and ToPort are Numbers."}, {'account_id': 6794, 'date': '2013-08-28 07:08:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

What is the Heat policy regarding CloudFormation schema? Do we care about maintaining full CFN compatibility?'}, {'account_id': 6794, 'date': '2013-08-28 07:10:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Christopher
the good link for the SecurityGroupEgress and SecurityGroupIngress properties is this one: http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSCloudFormation/latest/UserGuide/aws-properties-ec2-security-group-rule.html'}, {'account_id': 6794, 'date': '2013-08-28 07:18:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

After reviewing both of your comments, it seems that there is a confusion between EC2 Security Group Rule embedded type and AWS::EC2::SecurityGroupIngress type. The patch refers to the former type which represents FromPort and ToPort as String. 
I made the same mistake a while ago and indeed the AWS doc & implementation are not very clear...'}, {'account_id': 7135, 'date': '2013-08-29 06:50:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

ha, AWS docs... I agree that EC2 Security Group Rule embedded type is the right one to follow. Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 3098, 'date': '2013-08-29 16:13:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
Add schema for security group rule

This applies to the SecurityGroupEgress and SecurityGroupIngress
properties of the AWS::EC2::SecurityGroup resources.

Change-Id: I339227190db42707560f00cc825bc791d2bde5ce
Fixes: bug #1214333

commit_message:
Renaming in HA guide

- Quantum to OpenStack Networking
- Nova to OpenStack Compute
- Keystone to OpenStack Identity
- Glance to OpenStack Image

Change-Id: I67b7cd2c9a06d49ad8b22cdeb2810f9368563e82
Signed-off-by: Emilien Macchi <emilien.macchi@enovance.com>

subject: Adds support for Openstack Networking FWaaS (Firewall)

blueprint quantum-fwaas-devstack'}, {'account_id': 6641, 'date': '2013-07-16 00:07:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-07-16 00:07:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

New patchset patch-id matches previous patchset, but commit message has changed.'}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2013-07-17 08:36:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

If the following is set in localrc, then the class configuration gets set twice and the neutron server does not come up:
Q_SERVICE_PLUGIN_CLASSES=neutron.services.firewall.fwaas_plugin.FirewallPlugin

I believe we should be checking and setting this only once in such a case?'}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2013-07-17 08:41:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Actually I tried an install with just q-fwaas set in the localrc, and neither the service_plugins configuration was set, nor was the fwaas_driver.ini file created.'}, {'account_id': 6641, 'date': '2013-07-17 17:11:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Sumit, Did you set right git location for neutron to get fwaas code.
I tried on a new devstack  with changes set in stack.rc and it worked fine for me.

NEUTRON_REPO=https://review.openstack.org/openstack/neutron
NEUTRON_BRANCH=refs/changes/74/34074/29

NEUTRONCLIENT_REPO=https://review.openstack.org/openstack/python-neutronclient
NEUTRONCLIENT_BRANCH=refs/changes/87/33187/19'}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2013-07-17 18:22:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I had some problems in my setup, do disregard my previous comments for now, I will try again.

But the previous issue I mentioned is conformed:
Q_SERVICE_PLUGIN_CLASSES=neutron.services.firewall.fwaas_plugin.FirewallPlugin'}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2013-07-18 01:56:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

commit_message:
Add constructor args to swob.Request.blank

I knew webob.Request.blank could take most of the attributes on the class as
kwargs to blank, so I went and looked how.  It seems to work ok and is pretty
nice.

Change-Id: I72fae7c28f81c97768ee98b8ebcd69789a4c2e84

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-28 17:43:25.000000000', 'message': 'fix bad usage of exc_info=True

To use parameter exc_info in logging, here
(https://review.openstack.org/#/c/38077/) also uses some bad usage of
that. This patch will fix:
* use trackback.stacktrace() instead of exc_info
* use "Error: %s" % exc_info[1] (removing .message to follow PEP352)

Change-Id: Ia661ea9ce760f51359193904b77f7323434ed463
'}]
commit_message:
fix bad usage of exc_info=True

To use parameter exc_info in logging, here
(https://review.openstack.org/#/c/38077/) also uses some bad usage of
that. This patch will fix:
* use trackback.stacktrace() instead of exc_info
* use "Error: %s" % exc_info[1] (removing .message to follow PEP352)

Change-Id: Ia661ea9ce760f51359193904b77f7323434ed463

commit_message:
alarm: generate alarm_id in API

This isn't a detail of the storage, this is something we handle and
expose in the API, so the responsability for handling should be in the
API.
Also, they shouldn't exist any alarm without an id, so the model makes
it mandatory now.

Change-Id: I726ca74489007ee1d387bcb06b23af2f060ceb5f

commit_message:
Sets policy settings so V3 API extensions are discoverable

Adds the policy settings so the V3 API extensions
are by default discoverable through /v3/extensions. Some of
these policy settings were missed during the porting of
the extensions as the ability to make extensions not discoverable
was done part way through.

Partially implements blueprint nova-v3-api

Change-Id: If2efa15a437d97be8bc026fb04c46ec47eef056f

commit_message:
Adds support for security_groups for V3 API server create

Adds support for specifying the security group during the V3 API
server create to the security groups extensions. This was
accidentally missed during the initial port. Adds the
corresponding XML deserialization and unittests.

Partially implements blueprint nova-v3-api
Fixes bug #1208746

Change-Id: Ie9d9e03ae20357212b0f270d97a19a0d0f9b0557

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-29 15:04:08.000000000', 'message': 'Add mock to test-requirements

There are several changes which depend on using mock rather than mox for
unit tests:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/42474/
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/43161/

And the general trend seems to be to move from using mock over mox for
new tests (see blueprint mox-to-mock-conversion).

And given mock is listed in the global-requirements.txt file in the
openstack/requirements project, we should require mock for nova so we
can start using it.

Change-Id: Iaa0f233c28de2f92a237ee6d089858ee10bc6d2f
'}]
commit_message:
Add mock to test-requirements

There are several changes which depend on using mock rather than mox for
unit tests:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/42474/
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/43161/

And the general trend seems to be to move from using mock over mox for
new tests (see blueprint mox-to-mock-conversion).

And given mock is listed in the global-requirements.txt file in the
openstack/requirements project, we should require mock for nova so we
can start using it.

Change-Id: Iaa0f233c28de2f92a237ee6d089858ee10bc6d2f

This patch re-works swift content for the new configuration reference
structure.

The Object Storage configuration section is pared down, with
additional/optional features moved to a new file and section of the
document - adding to what was previously there in the Object Storage
Admin Guide.

New stub sections added for drive-audit, static web and form post.

One of the big changes is the move of all option tables to
common/tables.

These have been generated with a new script which converts swift
 conf files into docbook tables, and attempts to find descriptions
of those configuration options in swift's devref documentation.

Future work for this script: merged in with the autodoc tool
structure, add an 'update' mode.

Change-Id: I75a3c442e4734594bec202fecbe4a4272d297ac7
lp:restructure-documentation

commit_message:
Swift work for config reference

This patch re-works swift content for the new configuration reference
structure.

The Object Storage configuration section is pared down, with
additional/optional features moved to a new file and section of the
document - adding to what was previously there in the Object Storage
Admin Guide.

New stub sections added for drive-audit, static web and form post.

One of the big changes is the move of all option tables to
common/tables.

These have been generated with a new script which converts swift
 conf files into docbook tables, and attempts to find descriptions
of those configuration options in swift's devref documentation.

Future work for this script: merged in with the autodoc tool
structure, add an 'update' mode.

Change-Id: I75a3c442e4734594bec202fecbe4a4272d297ac7
lp:restructure-documentation

'}, {'account_id': 6939, 'date': '2013-07-29 15:43:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Basically I am -1 for this idea because:
    1. you can do it by boot-from-volume if you really want a local driver from ceph
    2. IF this BP get approved and merged, there will be sheepdog support, SAN support, EMC support...we are reinvent the wheel(cinder) and will make nova too complex
    3. thanks to the educate from AWS, user is usually expect high performance, low latency (similar to a physical hard disk) , low durability for local drive, and usually use it as swap/cache/tempfile/log, Is it a good idea to have ceph, which has good HA but less good performance(compared to physical disk) to address such expectation and usage?"}, {'account_id': 6939, 'date': '2013-07-29 15:44:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

Basically I am -1 for this idea because:
    1. you can do it by boot-from-volume if you really want a local driver from ceph
    2. IF this BP get approved and merged, there will be sheepdog support, SAN support, EMC support...we are reinvent the wheel(cinder) and will make nova too complex
    3. thanks to the educate from AWS, user is usually expect high performance, low latency (similar to a physical hard disk) , low durability for local drive, and usually use it as swap/cache/tempfile/log, Is it a good idea to have ceph, which has good HA but less good performance(compared to physical disk) to address such expectation and usage?'}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2013-07-31 15:45:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Actually, there was a Cinder session in last (havana) design summit to discuss the future of Nova local storage management: https://etherpad.openstack.org/havana-cinder-local-storage-library

My take from that session is basically Nova & Cinder folks agreed that in future local storage (local disk as a start) will be managed by Cinder. Vish even listed a step-by-step proposal on how we could finally get there. 

Sbastien, were you there in the discussion? IMHO, your bp proposal is totally heading the opposite direction. Cinder has is creating a local storage library 'brick' now. I'd suggest considering add RBD support there instead."}, {'account_id': 6984, 'date': '2013-07-31 20:42:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15: No score

No I wasn't aware of this initiative, which is in my humble opinion really good since it avoids code duplication and makes the whole cleaner. Actually, I recently had a discussion John Griffith about the LVM brick library implementation. However I know that it's still under work in process. I could tend to say that we should implement this BP first since the code is ready and then deprecate it later, just in case if the 'brick' does't make it for Havana. Apart from this, we could also put some efforts on this area I agree. Do you have any update about brick's progress?"}, {'account_id': 1107, 'date': '2013-08-01 01:57:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Winston: I agree brick or something like it is the long term solution, but it doesn't seem very close to ready yet. AFIACT there's no code proposed to use it in nova so far, and brick has been focused on abstracting out the attach code.

This patch seems like a good short term solution for Havana to me."}, {'account_id': 6984, 'date': '2013-08-01 07:53:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2013-08-01 14:51:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

Josh, Sbastien, I totally understand that having Ceph to support instance storage can be very useful in certain use cases.  What I trying to say is, designing and implementing a stable feature like this needs to be careful especially when it may involve cross project efforts. IMHO getting something in a project and then deprecate it pretty soon (or just knowing it will soon be deprecated) is _not_ the right thing to do for the sake of OpenStack.  Can we manage to keep stable user interface and experience even using two very different implementations (rbd in Nova vs. brick lib)? Even if we can, pushing likely-to-be-dreprecated-soon code is not a good practice just to get some features into OpenStack. I'm sorry I wasn't aware this BP until yesterday, otherwise I should have suggested you put efforts into 'brick' much earlier."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-08-02 20:46:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Before going any further the blueprint must be approved."}, {'account_id': 6737, 'date': '2013-08-07 14:32:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(4 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-08-07 21:46:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15: Do not merge

It sounds like brick is the better long term direction here, and the Cinder folks have brick integration with Nova targeted at Havana.  It doesn't seem like a good idea to merge something that we expect to be deprecated shortly after, especially when this could set brick integration backwards."}, {'account_id': 1525, 'date': '2013-08-07 23:23:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Is there any possibility we can reconsider this patch?

The code is done and it adds functionality which is immensely useful. There are more environments being launched everyday with CEPH and the current workflow for utilizing this storage via BFV is odd at best.  The lack of direct RBD support means that any environments deployed with CEPH as the exclusive storage backend cannot leverage a substantial amount of Nova functionality.

For example, flavors have no meaning in a pure CEPH environment, because everything needs to be done with volumes.  As such, bulk instance launching does not work via Horizon, since there are several steps needed to provision a single BFV instance.

I think it's a mistake to deny working code we have today, in favor of code which may exist at some indeterminate point in the future.  It's a bit more idealist than I think we should be, given the hoops users are having to jump through with their CEPH deployments today.

My two cents."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-08-12 19:11:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

related discussion: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-August/013480.html'}, {'account_id': 7593, 'date': '2013-08-19 03:52:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 16.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-19 04:46:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 16: Doesn't seem to work

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-08 10:25:47.000000000', 'message': 'Add RBD supporting to libvirt for creating local volume

This patch implement creating local volume to Ceph cluster, and create snapshot
with root parition to upload to glance with volume in Ceph cluster.

The path to create local volume(root, swap or ephemeral):
At first, libvirt will check the image the request specified in _base
directory, fetch the image from glance if not. Then the executer will enter my
hack code and import the image to ceph cluster from _base directory.  Finally,
qemu-img will attach the rbd://xxxx to VM.

The path to create snapshot with root image:
1 If the instance is running and because rbd support parallel access, we can
use qemu-img converting the root image to a raw image in local filesystem as
snapshot directly.
2. Upload the snapshot to Glance
Because the libvirt code implementing creat snapshot is complicated and consider
the other file format without parallel access supporting, there exists two path
to implement it. They are in imagebackend.py and driver.py:_live_snapshot
respectively.

Change-Id: Id97de5c9af4ddc5c58493a5cef21b52386afac3e
'}, {'created': '2013-07-08 10:36:40.000000000', 'message': 'Add RBD supporting to libvirt for creating local volume

This patch implement creating local volume to Ceph cluster, and create snapshot
with root parition to upload to glance with volume in Ceph cluster.

The path to create local volume(root, swap or ephemeral):
At first, libvirt will check the image the request specified in _base
directory, fetch the image from glance if not. Then the executer will enter my
hack code and import the image to ceph cluster from _base directory.  Finally,
qemu-img will attach the rbd://xxxx to VM.

The path to create snapshot with root image:
1 If the instance is running and because rbd support parallel access, we can
use qemu-img converting the root image to a raw image in local filesystem as
snapshot directly.
2. Upload the snapshot to Glance
Because the libvirt code implementing creat snapshot is complicated and consider
the other file format without parallel access supporting, there exists two path
to implement it. They are in imagebackend.py and driver.py:_live_snapshot
respectively.

bp: Bring RBD support to libvirt_images_type
Change-Id: Id97de5c9af4ddc5c58493a5cef21b52386afac3e
'}, {'created': '2013-07-09 05:36:46.000000000', 'message': 'Add RBD supporting to libvirt for creating local volume

This patch implement creating local volume to Ceph cluster, and create snapshot
with root parition to upload to glance with volume in Ceph cluster.

The path to create local volume(root, swap or ephemeral):
At first, libvirt will check the image the request specified in _base
directory, fetch the image from glance if not. Then the executer will enter my
hack code and import the image to ceph cluster from _base directory.  Finally,
qemu-img will attach the rbd://xxxx to VM.

The path to create snapshot with root image:
1 Because rbd support parallel access, whatever the instance is running or not,
we always use "qemu-img convert" command to convert the root image in ceph
cluster to raw format and store it in local filesystem directly.
2. Upload the snapshot to Glance and delete the local snapshot.

bp: Bring RBD support to libvirt_images_type
Change-Id: Id97de5c9af4ddc5c58493a5cef21b52386afac3e

'}, {'created': '2013-07-12 14:35:00.000000000', 'message': 'Add RBD supporting to libvirt for creating local volume

This patch implements these:
1. Creating local volume from Ceph cluster.
2. Creating the snapshot of root parition and upload it to glance.

To create local volume(root, swap or ephemeral):
At first, libvirt will check the image the request specified in _base
directory, fetch the image from glance if not. Then the executer will call
`create_image()` that imagebackend implemented and import the image to ceph
cluster from _base directory.  Finally, qemu-img will attach the rbd://xxxx to
VM.

To create snapshot with root image:
1 Because rbd support parallel access, whatever the instance is running or not,
we always use "qemu-img convert" command to convert the root image in ceph
cluster to raw format and store it in local filesystem directly.
2. Upload the snapshot to Glance and delete the local snapshot.

Implement: blueprint bring-rbd-support-libvirt-images-type
Change-Id: Id97de5c9af4ddc5c58493a5cef21b52386afac3e
'}, {'created': '2013-07-13 04:05:18.000000000', 'message': 'Add RBD supporting to libvirt for creating local volume

The block storage in OpenStack is divided into Nova and Cinder, Nova is
responsible for local volume such as root, swap and ephemeral partition. Cinder
is responsible for normal volume(global volume?). This mode will make difficult
for planning storage allocation. In order to improve the availability of
storage capacity and reduce the complexity of storage allocation, implementing
the unified storage for local volume in Nova and volumes in Cinder is
necessary.

Now Nova supports lvm backend for creating local volume. Ceph as a Cinder
backend we want to implement it too in Nova.

This patch implements these:
1. Creating local volume from Ceph cluster.
2. Creating the snapshot of root parition and upload it to glance.

To create local volume(root, swap or ephemeral):
At first, libvirt will check the image the request specified in _base
directory, fetch the image from glance if not. Then the executer will call
`create_image()` that imagebackend implemented and import the image to ceph
cluster from _base directory.  Finally, qemu-img will attach the rbd://xxxx to
VM.

To create snapshot with root image:
1 Because rbd support parallel access, whatever the instance is running or not,
we always use "qemu-img convert" command to convert the root image in ceph
cluster to raw format and store it in local filesystem directly.
2. Upload the snapshot to Glance and delete the local snapshot.

Implement: blueprint bring-rbd-support-libvirt-images-type
Change-Id: Id97de5c9af4ddc5c58493a5cef21b52386afac3e

commit_message:
Add RBD supporting to libvirt for creating local volume

The block storage in OpenStack is divided into Nova and Cinder, Nova is
responsible for local volume such as root, swap and ephemeral partition. Cinder
is responsible for normal volume(global volume?). This mode will make difficult
for planning storage allocation. In order to improve the availability of
storage capacity and reduce the complexity of storage allocation, implementing
the unified storage for local volume in Nova and volumes in Cinder is
necessary.

Now Nova supports lvm backend for creating local volume. Ceph as a Cinder
backend we want to implement it too in Nova.

This patch add RBD backend to libvirt image backend, and users can use specify
rbd as the source of root, ephemeral and swap partition.

Implement: blueprint bring-rbd-support-libvirt-images-type
Change-Id: Id97de5c9af4ddc5c58493a5cef21b52386afac3e

'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-08-09 10:49:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Thanks for this Bob.

In general this looks good but I wonder if we should base our calculation on when the patch set was created rather when when each revision gets posted. I'm not sure we have a hook for that... so perhaps using 'revisionCreatedOn' is the best we can do for now?"}, {'account_id': 6735, 'date': '2013-08-09 10:55:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

There is details on when the original patch was posted - but if the reviewer has been slow to update it (or it was abandoned and revived) then I think that there are patches that could significantly skew the weight.

I think basing it on the time since the last revision posted is better because it represents the time that a patch has been waiting for core review (i.e. previously it might have had minus scores needing some or potentially substantial change)'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-08-29 15:10:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-29 15:10:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

commit_message:
Added time-based score for patches

Based on the number of days since the last patch was posted

Also added a tooltip to explain scores

Change-Id: I1f13a97ddd8714297a331be91146f9742bbb9766

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-31 23:54:28.000000000', 'message': "Remove broken config_drive image_href support.

image_href support has not been working since at least shortly before
Folsom release.  This is a good indication that this functionality is not
used.  As far as I can tell, the docs also do not match what was
supported.  An image ID was required, but docs show examples with full
hrefs.

DocImpact

http://docs.openstack.org/developer/nova/api_ext/ext_config_drive.html

References to supporting image_hrefs should be removed.

Docs also state that 'true' or 'True' (depending on if you use
XML or JSON) or empty strings are returned for detail/show.  The
nova code seems to actually return '1' or an empty string or None.

This has been corrected in this patch to return 'True' (always
capitalized) or '' if it is enabled/disabled respectively.

This patch also removes the hack that passed a config_drive_id via
the Instance dictionary when config_drive_id is not a valid Column for
Instance.

Fixes bug 1186401

Change-Id: Iced7bc8e278cb9f208183f1dbb7a293675a47eae

commit_message:
Remove broken config_drive image_href support.

image_href support has not been working since at least shortly before
Folsom release.  This is a good indication that this functionality is not
used.  As far as I can tell, the docs also do not match what was
supported.  An image ID was required, but docs show examples with full
hrefs.

DocImpact

http://docs.openstack.org/developer/nova/api_ext/ext_config_drive.html

References to supporting image_hrefs should be removed.

This patch also removes the hack that passed a config_drive_id via
the Instance dictionary when config_drive_id is not a valid Column for
Instance.

Fixes bug 1186401

Change-Id: Iced7bc8e278cb9f208183f1dbb7a293675a47eae

Remove  useLatestSuffixInPdfUrl

Remove useLatestSuffixInPdfUrl from Admin User, it's not needed
for OpenStack manuals.

This is related to bug #1215241

commit_message:
Added 'nova migration-list' command

This command lets Admin's list migrations by applying filters

Implements: blueprint list-resizes-through-admin-api
Change-Id: I587c62dab537186cfc8b387fbc46cdb56fb9976c

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-28 19:24:15.000000000', 'message': 'Update DocBook validating schema to 5.1CR1

Update the RelaxNG schema used by tools/validate.py to 5.1CR1.

This schema is used to validate individual files. The new schema
should allow any entity to be at the root. This should eliminate
false negative xinclude-related validation errors.

Change-Id: I24cfe9bf75fd776eff11fcd1753ded0e7e8a39bd
'}]
commit_message:
Update DocBook validating schema to 5.1CR1

Update the RelaxNG schema used by tools/validate.py to 5.1CR1.

This schema is used to validate individual files. The new schema
should allow any entity to be at the root. This should eliminate
false negative xinclude-related validation errors.

Change-Id: I24cfe9bf75fd776eff11fcd1753ded0e7e8a39bd

Hi, I'm building a monitoring tab into the Instance page, using your ceilometer API. I encounter some issues when I use your implementation. Indeed when I try to access attribute like disk.read.bytes I am stuck by python which think it is an attribute chaining. So I have just a question (I am a beginner). Why do not we use underscores instead of points i.e: disk_read_bytes?"}, {'account_id': 1952, 'date': '2013-07-16 03:59:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Maxime, you are right and it should be an issue for python.'}, {'account_id': 7976, 'date': '2013-07-16 14:31:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Here is my hack to change data access, I don't know if it can be useful, but I don't really figured out a clean way to perform this.

class GlobalDiskUsage(APIDictWrapper):
    _attrs = ["tenant", "user", "resource", "disk_read_bytes",
              "disk_read_requests", "disk_write_bytes",
              "disk_write_requests"]

    def __init__(self, apidict):
        super(GlobalDiskUsage, self).__init__(
            {key.replace('.', '_'): value for key, value in apidict.items()}
        )'}, {'account_id': 1952, 'date': '2013-07-16 17:10:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-16 17:59:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Works for me

In ceilometer.py, global_usage_get signature has changed. You now pass a usage_id which has a specific format, but in my case I get tenant, user and resource separately and I have to format them in order to use this function. Is there possible to revert to the previous signature with separate user_id, tenant_id, resource_id and manage the split in an other function?'}, {'account_id': 4978, 'date': '2013-08-15 13:03:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Hi Brooklyn,

Could you answer Maxime's comment and give some background on the signature change? If usage_id is built out of 3 pieces of information one needs to send anyway, maybe it does make sense to receive the 3 arguments separately and build the usage_id out of it.

Due to the delay, this probably needs a rebase."}, {'account_id': 7585, 'date': '2013-08-16 11:26:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(4 inline comments)

Issues I found are commented inline.

Will need rebase due to current pep8 commits. 

Otherwise it's job well done. Looking forward to have this in the master."}, {'account_id': 1952, 'date': '2013-08-16 13:41:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Hi Maxime, if you want to use this in your own project, you can separate usage_id 	into 3 fields. I merge the 3 into 1 because I think it's a unique id for  one usage report, just like instance_uuid for one instance."}, {'account_id': 7585, 'date': '2013-08-16 16:12:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: (2 inline comments)

commit_message:
Add ceilometer api and the tests for it

Adding ceilometer api basic function wrappers.
Adding Class wrapper of each ceilometer object.

Adding ceilometer general usage wrappers for common statistics over
list of Resources and ResourceAggregates.

Adding specific table statistics wrappers.

Adding tests and test data for Ceilometer API.

Best to be tested with commit for resource usage panel at:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/35590/ - this commit is for the
test purpose only.

Link to bp: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/horizon/+spec/ceilometer

Implements bp ceilometer.
Change-Id: I5b3392de8bae2be8cbcba7a580af669676e54052

[{'created': '2013-08-20 23:33:46.000000000', 'message': "Move prep_resize paths to use objects

Converts calls to compute's prep_resize to pass a new-world instance
object.

This does not convert the scheduler prep_resize method which is still
called on reschedules.  It will soon be deprecated anyway.

Related to blueprint unified-object-model

Change-Id: I7a150f119547595aec962d5e5a8d2ab815d0b6c5

commit_message:
Change prep_resize paths to use objects

Converts calls to compute's prep_resize to pass a new-world instance
object.

This does not convert the scheduler prep_resize method which is still
called on reschedules.  It will soon be deprecated anyway.

Related to blueprint unified-object-model

Change-Id: I7a150f119547595aec962d5e5a8d2ab815d0b6c5

commit_message:
Removes fixed ips extension from V3 API

The fixed ip extension was one of the first ported to the V3 API
but a later decision around not supporting nova network in the V3 API
means that this extension is not required for V3. The fixed ip extension
only supports nova network, not neutron and the same functionality
can be accessed directly through neutron.

Also changes some extension tests to use a different extension
for white/black list testing

Partially implements bp nova-v3-api

Change-Id: Ie589170e863ee489661e789c5134ed8349ced279

commit_message:
Proper usage of _resource property in quotas

Use resources instead of _resources. This is necessary because _resources
actually does not contain all resources in VolumeTypeQuotaEngine, and there
is property-method `resources' was introduced for this.

Change-Id: Iac85497a956e7c3a8c58bb38337a63d0d5fabc8f

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-09 12:02:21.000000000', 'message': "parameterize fileutils removal functions

Currently delete_if_exists() and consequently
remove_path_on_error() only support single files.
So to handle dirs, or trees or higher level operations
it's useful to be able to specify how to remove.

* openstack/common/fileutils.py (delete_if_exists):
Allow passing a removal function.
(remove_path_on_error): Likewise.
* tests/unit/test_fileutils.py (test_dir_present):
Demonstrate/test removal of empty dirs.
(test_remove_dir): Likewise.
(test_remove): Ensure the remove param is honored.

Change-Id: I0ea2498048f09af5f1b9c1bddba677c5813fb2f8

commit_message:
parameterize fileutils removal functions

Currently delete_if_exists() and consequently
remove_path_on_error() only support single files.
So to handle dirs, or trees or higher level operations
it's useful to be able to specify how to remove.

* openstack/common/fileutils.py (delete_if_exists):
Allow passing a removal function.
(remove_path_on_error): Likewise.
* tests/unit/test_fileutils.py (test_dir_present):
Demonstrate/test removal of empty dirs.
(test_remove_dir): Likewise.
(test_remove): Ensure the remove param is honored.

[{'created': '2013-08-09 06:51:44.000000000', 'message': "Adjust some APIs' interface of hbase and logging storage backend

To keep in line with sqlalchemy and mongodb, which support pagination
query for methods get_resources, get_meters, get_alarms, we adjust the
interfaces of these methods for hbase and logging storage backend.
It is part of bp/paginate-db-search.

Implements blueprint paginate-db-search

commit_message:
Raise NotImplementedError if pagination query be called for Hbase

It is part of bp/paginate-db-search.

Implements blueprint paginate-db-search

Change-Id: Ie6ee96570139f2273ce329d17d722ed176b28268

@jgriffith, I consider current approach is correct as thingee thoughts and it's easy/good to migrate to multi-attach case.


Acutally current issue about this change is about 'non-mutable metadata' as thingee mentioned. This PS using normal volume metadata to saving 'readonly' flag and 'attached mode' of the volume, but without 'non-mutable metadata' any user has access to change metadata. So i'm want to make sure what's the team position about this, since 'non-mutable metadata' seems a dedicated feature to me so can I address that part in a separated patch? it's overkill to this r/o-attach change IMO. Or you'd prefer do that in this patch? I just want to get this approved BP done in time.

thanks."}, {'account_id': 6506, 'date': '2013-08-23 11:43:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: (5 inline comments)

commit_message:
Adding Read-Only volume attaching support to Cinder

1. Adding an API extension to allow clients set volume Read-Only flag on
demand.
2. Require client to provide and be aware of volume attaching mode when
they call 'os-attach' API.
3. Adding a 'access_mode' field to connection info which
'os-initialize_connection' API returned. This field should be used by
client such as Nova to use correct mode accessing attached volume.
Currently access mode can be 'rw' or 'ro'.
4. In future, the driver within Cinder need to ensure the volume be
exposed under the correct access mode which connection info described,
for example backend should set volume to readonly mode when connection
info ask client using 'ro' access mode consume attached volume. That
means Read-Only is not only a attaching mode but also a status for a
volume.

blueprint read-only-volumes

Change-Id: I4c84614d6541d5f7c358abadb957da7b8c3d9c48
Signed-off-by: Zhi Yan Liu <zhiyanl@cn.ibm.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-29 08:10:43.000000000', 'message': 'Add event for device remove

this is a very draft event process for device remove:

1.change the event framework to  a nofiy chain, so
libvirt itself can recive the intresting event.

2.a python event is setup, when detach the pci device
we wait on it to complete.

in this way, we got event to ensure the device is remove
before we go on...

XXXX problem:
1) i setup libvirt in ubuntu, and dev stack, there is no event
support ....  so no on hardware testing be done

2) use libvirt event like this seems broken the event process logic
: now, we recive event only in compute node, and only support
one listener.

--------------------------------
there can be done in another way,

1) libvirt do the detach and return,
2) compoute node receive the detach event, and wait there.
3) this method keep current event frame no change.

in either way, seems we might need talk a got...

Change-Id: I23a368d4b7017343783e1b8a35ad383d00eb9031
signed-off-by: Yongli He <yongli.he@intel.com>

commit_message:
Add event for device remove

this is a very draft event process for device remove:

1.change the event framework to  a nofiy chain, so
libvirt itself can recive the intresting event.

2.a python event is setup, when detach the pci device
we wait on it to complete.

in this way, we got event to ensure the device is remove
before we go on...

XXXX problem:
1) i setup libvirt in ubuntu, and dev stack, there is no event
support ....  so no on hardware testing be done

2) use libvirt event like this seems broken the event process logic
: now, we recive event only in compute node, and only support
one listener.

--------------------------------
there can be done in another way,

1) libvirt do the detach and return,
2) compoute node receive the detach event, and wait there.
3) this method keep current event frame no change.

in either way, seems we might need talk a got...

Change-Id: I23a368d4b7017343783e1b8a35ad383d00eb9031
signed-off-by: Yongli He <yongli.he@intel.com>

commit_message:
Add large-ops option to tox

Add new option because we want to keep separate tox jobs for each
jenkins job.

Part of the regression test for bug 1199433.

Change-Id: I4e59d79d3ce3a9621243a81b7da5d9c3abaf1d6f

commit_message:
Hide form tooltip when form closes on escape key

Fixes #1215277

Form tooltips used in every form.
After form closes on escape button tooltip stays on screen
until the page is refreshed.
This fix listen escape key pressing and close opened tooltip.

Change-Id: Ie01336787a3bd11ed967e085ee7dda4616441cc7

[{'created': '2013-08-08 08:58:04.000000000', 'message': "fix the Host's attribute problem

change the 'host' attribute to 'host_name' attribute

Change-Id: Ie76ba04da7592a596ab728fec981e9a1dbcc6a5f
Fixes: bug 1210043
"}, {'created': '2013-08-09 05:20:38.000000000', 'message': 'change 'Host' object's 'host' attribute to 'host_name'

The function __repr__ of Host class which is located in hosts.py try to
access 'host' attribute, source code is "self.host",But in fact, Host object
don't has this attribute, it should be 'host_name'! We can find this attribute
from nova/api/openstack/compute/contrib/hosts.py file.

So I simply change 'self.host' to 'self.host_name'.

Change-Id: Ie76ba04da7592a596ab728fec981e9a1dbcc6a5f
Fixes: bug 1210043
'}]
commit_message:
change 'Host' object's 'host' attribute to 'host_name'

The function __repr__ of Host class which is located in hosts.py try to
access 'host' attribute, source code is "self.host",But in fact, Host object
don't has this attribute, it should be 'host_name'! We can find this attribute
from nova/api/openstack/compute/contrib/hosts.py file.

So I simply change 'self.host' to 'self.host_name'.

Change-Id: Ie76ba04da7592a596ab728fec981e9a1dbcc6a5f
Fixes: bug 1210043

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-29 00:43:19.000000000', 'message': "Clean up some of the proxy unit tests.

Since we've got machinery to catch HTTPException errors that happens
after the proxy server's __call__ method but before the individual
GET()/POST()/etc. methods, we shouldn't just call
GET()/POST()/etc. Instead, we should use swob.Request's get_response()
method, or otherwise actually call the proxy application. That way we
can have the code raise HTTPBadRequest, but the test just gets a
plain old response with a 400 status code, just like you'd expect.

Earlier changes fixed some of the tests; this commit fixes some
more. In the interest of not having a gigantic diff, this only gets
about half the proxy's unit tests, and the others will be done in a
subsequent commit.

Change-Id: Iaca32e74a8f4499440e655c207a1012e14486c74
"}]
commit_message:
Clean up some of the proxy unit tests.

Since we've got machinery to catch HTTPException errors that happens
after the proxy server's __call__ method but before the individual
GET()/POST()/etc. methods, we shouldn't just call
GET()/POST()/etc. Instead, we should use swob.Request's get_response()
method, or otherwise actually call the proxy application. That way we
can have the code raise HTTPBadRequest, but the test just gets a
plain old response with a 400 status code, just like you'd expect.

Earlier changes fixed some of the tests; this commit fixes some
more. In the interest of not having a gigantic diff, this only gets
about half the proxy's unit tests, and the others will be done in a
subsequent commit.

Change-Id: Iaca32e74a8f4499440e655c207a1012e14486c74

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-14 04:50:16.000000000', 'message': 'Fix HTTP response for PortInUse during boot (v3 API)

If an in use port is passed as a network parameter in the request, Nova API
should raise an HTTPConflict (409) error. This was fixed in commit
48b31c9a1f5d2a45d881e70c6223411c5abbcb72 for the V2 API but not the V3 API.

Fixes bug 1212098

Change-Id: I94429f2c04cf81cb88a8739f65a49aa7ca0d49bd
'}, {'created': '2013-08-16 03:26:41.000000000', 'message': 'Fix HTTP response for PortInUse during boot (v3 API)

If an in use port is passed as a network parameter in the request, Nova API
should raise an HTTPConflict (409) error. This was fixed in commit
48b31c9a1f5d2a45d881e70c6223411c5abbcb72 for the V2 API but not the V3 API.

Fixes bug 1212098

Change-Id: I94429f2c04cf81cb88a8739f65a49aa7ca0d49bd
'}]
commit_message:
Fix HTTP response for PortInUse during boot (v3 API)

If an in use port is passed as a network parameter in the request, Nova API
should raise an HTTPConflict (409) error. This was fixed in commit
48b31c9a1f5d2a45d881e70c6223411c5abbcb72 for the V2 API but not the V3 API.

Fixes bug 1212098

Change-Id: I94429f2c04cf81cb88a8739f65a49aa7ca0d49bd

This commit fixes test_admin_catalog_list() so that it tests more
specific details of the admin catalog. It also removes the test's

commit_message:
Fix test_admin_catalog_list

This commit fixes test_admin_catalog_list() so that it tests more
specific details of the admin catalog. It also removes the test's
dependency on each table in the output having a service label. This
dependency was occasionally causing a failure if the test ran at the
same time as the keystone api tests.

Fixes bug 1217159

Change-Id: I4446abb86a3f1f6514fc9de1d00c06f82943b9d9

commit_message:
Add /usr/sbin and /sbin to $PATH route

Depending on the system configuration, /usr/sbin and /sbin can be not
available to the user executing the script, and failing to boot
the seed image due to the missing route to the arp command.

In Fedora, Ubuntu and Debian arp is located in /usr/sbin, meanwhile
in Centos it's located in /sbin .

Change-Id: I34be00348626205929329962d7e2998b4dca55f3

'}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2013-08-20 18:51:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Overall looking good... A few notes:

1. There should definitely be a section about the policy files in the docs.

2. The policy file settings should probably be added to the local_settings.py example file as well.

3. The rules.py file seems like a good concept, but won't scale well as more services try to cram more things into it. I think it'd be better to keep those rule groupings in individual files per services, within a new top-level "policy" or "rules" module (use your judgment).

4. The current implementation of having to import that code and write it out every time is pretty redundant. I think we could probably add this to the base Action code so you could simply specify a set of rules and it would check those *prior* to executing the "allowed" method. That'd be a bit more DRY.

Otherwise this looks pretty straightforward and solid.'}, {'account_id': 5623, 'date': '2013-08-23 20:21:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 5623, 'date': '2013-08-23 20:40:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-19 20:13:55.000000000', 'message': "Adding RBAC policy system and checks for identity

Adding file based RBAC engine for Horizon using copies of nova and
keystone policy.json files

Policy engine builds on top of oslo incubator policy.py, fileutils
was also pulled from oslo incubator as a dependency of policy.py

When Horizon runs and a policy check is made, a path and mapping of
services to policy files is used to load the rules into the policy
engine.  Each check is mapped to a service type and validated.  This
extra level of mapping is required because the policy.json files
may each contain a 'default' rule or unqualified (no service name
include) rule.  Additionally, maintaining separate policy.json
files per service will allow easier syncing with the service
projects.

The engine allows for compound 'and' checks at this time.  E.g.,
the way the Create User action is written, multiple APIs are
called to read data (roles, projects) and more are required to
update data (grants, user).

Other workflows e.g., Edit Project,  should have separate save
actions per step as they are unrelated.  Only the applicable
policy checks to that step were added.  The separating unrelated
steps saves will should be future work.

The underlying engine supports more rule types that are used in the
underlying policy.json files.

Policy checks were added for all actions on tables in the Identity
Panel only.  And the service policy files imported are limited in
this commit to reduce scope of the change.

Finally, the benefit Horizon has is that the underlying APIs will
correct us if we get it wrong, so if a policy file is not found for
a particular service, permission is assumed and the actual API call
to the service will fail if the action isn't authorized for that user.

Implements: blueprint rbac

Change-Id: I4a4a71163186b973229a0461b165c16936bc10e5

commit_message:
Adding RBAC policy system and checks for identity

Adding file based RBAC engine for Horizon using copies of nova and
keystone policy.json files

Policy engine builds on top of oslo incubator policy.py, fileutils
was also pulled from oslo incubator as a dependency of policy.py

When Horizon runs and a policy check is made, a path and mapping of
services to policy files is used to load the rules into the policy
engine.  Each check is mapped to a service type and validated.  This
extra level of mapping is required because the policy.json files
may each contain a 'default' rule or unqualified (no service name
include) rule.  Additionally, maintaining separate policy.json
files per service will allow easier syncing with the service
projects.

The engine allows for compound 'and' checks at this time.  E.g.,
the way the Create User action is written, multiple APIs are
called to read data (roles, projects) and more are required to
update data (grants, user).

Other workflows e.g., Edit Project,  should have separate save
actions per step as they are unrelated.  Only the applicable
policy checks to that step were added.  The separating unrelated
steps saves will should be future work.

The underlying engine supports more rule types that are used in the
underlying policy.json files.

Policy checks were added for all actions on tables in the Identity
Panel only.  And the service policy files imported are limited in
this commit to reduce scope of the change.

Additionally, changes were made to the base action class to add
support or setting policy rules and an overridable method for
determining the policy check target. This reduces the need for
redundant code in each action policy check.

Note, the benefit Horizon has is that the underlying APIs will
correct us if we get it wrong, so if a policy file is not found for
a particular service, permission is assumed and the actual API call
to the service will fail if the action isn't authorized for that user.

Finally, adding documentation regarding policy enforcement.

Implements: blueprint rbac

Change-Id: I4a4a71163186b973229a0461b165c16936bc10e5

commit_message:
Use assertEqual instead of assertEquals

Closes-Bug: #1218185

For unittest, assertEquals is deprecated in py3, use assertEqual
instead.

Change-Id: Ia71b51a0f2625aec5fb4644853a79c2ea80a799c

Volume Type deletion should not be allowed if volumes present with that type.

Added method to retrieve volumes associated with type.
Closes-Bug: #1215329

commit_message:
Use common create_keypair method for autoscaling

The scenario test for autoscaling was implemented at the same time
with cleanup patch of create_keypair methods, and the cleanup patch
could not cover autoscaling test.
This patch covers autoscaling test.

Change-Id: Ibf4e98a9d4616c1dc6d2f08bde3d04a40b910067

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-28 05:48:02.000000000', 'message': 'Adds else clause and TODO in storage tests

Fixes bug #1217688

Addresses minor issues that were raised in the code review comments
for Patch Set 10 of "Add SQLAlchemy implementation of groupby"
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/41597/

1) Adds else clause to test_group_by_with_query_filter_multiple in
   class StatisticsGroupByTest in
   tests/storage/test_storage_scenarios.py

   The else clause ensures that all possible values for 'project_id'
   and 'resource_id' are covered when checking the values returned
   by get_meter_statistics().

2) Adds TODO comments for tests that are not implemented for class
   StatisticsGroupBy in tests/storage/test_storage_scenarios.py

   The tests that have not been implemented are ones involving
   metadata fields, since group by with metadata fields has not yet
   been implemented.

Change-Id: I55cc0cb6cc791708c9b8038787d712760f9515df
'}, {'created': '2013-08-28 05:52:38.000000000', 'message': 'Adds else and TODO in statistics storage tests

commit_message:
Adds else and TODO in statistics storage tests

Fixes bug #1217688

Addresses minor issues that were raised in the code review comments
for Patch Set 10 of "Add SQLAlchemy implementation of groupby"
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/41597/

The issues were in the StatisticsGroupByTest class of the storage
driver tests.

1) Adds else clause to test_group_by_with_query_filter_multiple

   The else clause ensures that all possible values for 'project_id'
   and 'resource_id' are covered when checking the values returned
   by get_meter_statistics().

2) Adds TODO comments for tests that are not implemented

   The tests that have not been implemented are ones involving
   metadata fields, since group by with metadata fields has not yet
   been implemented.

Change-Id: I55cc0cb6cc791708c9b8038787d712760f9515df

commit_message:
Removing support for the legacy commands

The legacy commands has been dropped from diablo to essex migration, so the related documentation has been removed

Change-Id: I705ecbde0d35507d9fe1e4385d8f4f06c7c0f4ff

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-13 17:47:57.000000000', 'message': 'Introduce Invalid* EC2 error codes

Following new EC2 exceptions are rised instead of useless EC2APIError:

 * InvalidKeyPairNotFoundEC2
 * InvalidPermissionDuplicateEC2
 * InvalidGroupDuplicateEC2

Nova exceptions raised outside of EC2 API are translated to corresponding
Invalid* EC2 error codes.

Implements: blueprint ec2-error-codes
Change-Id: Ica5cdf4a9662b4b569ded1f1b1931b9a3cdaa9f3
'}, {'created': '2013-08-26 19:17:37.000000000', 'message': 'Introduce Invalid* EC2 error codes

commit_message:
Introduce Invalid* EC2 error codes

ec2_code attribute with valid EC2 error code was added to several
Nova exceptions to allow simple error code mapping in EC2 API.

Implements: blueprint ec2-error-codes

Change-Id: Ica5cdf4a9662b4b569ded1f1b1931b9a3cdaa9f3

commit_message:
Add db.block_device_mapping_get_by_id

Add a new db API method for getting a block device mapping for a given
volume ID.  This is needed when Cinder calls over to Nova asking nova to
complete a snapshot operation on its behalf.

Related to blueprint qemu-assisted-snapshots

Change-Id: If3f011e2db14235f4137c9d9cb610f0c4cd7954a

subject: Add volume snapshot APIs to driver interface

interface.  This is needed to be able to do hypervisor assisted snapshot
operations.

Part of blueprint qemu-assisted-snapshots

commit_message:
Add volume snapshot APIs to driver interface

Add volume_snapshot_create and volume_snapshot_delete to the virt driver
interface.  This is needed to be able to do hypervisor assisted snapshot
operations.

Part of blueprint qemu-assisted-snapshots

Change-Id: I933e000ee56430365f9e380196714f43a85f147f

recheck no bug'}, {'account_id': 7135, 'date': '2013-08-29 01:09:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Clint, Thanks for raising the concern. The root cause is that the remote exceptions are no longer wrapped in RemoteError as they were before. My initial attempt was to catch HeatException, because oslo rpc.common reconstructs an Engine exception to a subclass of it with "_Remote" postfix for the subclass name on Heat-API side. However we also need to handle other exceptions which are not descendant of HeatException. We have AttributeError and ValueError mapped to InvalidParameterValue, and all the rest mapped to InternalFailure.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-29 01:33:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

[{'created': '2013-08-28 16:13:08.000000000', 'message': 'Fix CFN API error responses

A remote exception (included in conf.allowed_rpc_exception_modules)
is now restored to a subclass of its original type (with the
exception of non heap types which will always be restored to its
original type). Catching rpc_common.RemoteError is not enough
anymore.

Fixes bug #1214831

Change-Id: Iae3ce0c9d0d3f6565fab25ec899f83f19d46e81b
'}]
commit_message:
Fix CFN API error responses

A remote exception (included in conf.allowed_rpc_exception_modules)
is now restored to a subclass of its original type (with the
exception of non heap types which will always be restored to its
original type). Catching rpc_common.RemoteError is not enough
anymore.

Fixes bug #1214831

Change-Id: Iae3ce0c9d0d3f6565fab25ec899f83f19d46e81b

commit_message:
Fix the Domain context for Projects panel

Add display of Domain ID and Domain Name in the Create and Update
Projects page to give user a hint where the Project will be created.
For Keystone V2, the two fields will be hidden.

When the Domain Context is set, the Project will be created in that
Domain Context. Otherwise, the Project will be created in the Domain
of the logon user.

On project creation, the listing of available users and groups will
be based on the Domain where it will be created. While on project
update, the listing of available users and groups will be based on
the Domain of the Project.

Fixes bug 1215196

Change-Id: Ia2ab25956621d01c2173e08402241b7f60401e0f

commit_message:
Implement assignment of Domain Roles to Group

Added Domain Groups step in the Domain Update workflow for managing
domain-role assignment to Groups.

Change-Id: I882f9213ab8d72032d542dc45558e9479a86741e
Implements: blueprint group-domain-role-assignment

commit_message:
Deprecate conductor migration_create()

Converts the 1 use of conductor migration_create() to use the object
model, instead.

Related to blueprint unified-object-model

Change-Id: I5d8cf38d10d1092f2890b4f381337d188f4a7cf2
